questions.text:
Choose the appropriate option with respect to the following image
  1. The mosquito exhibits a hunch back, when at rest
  2. This is the only mosquito which has no siphon tube.
  3. It is also called as ‘Tiger mosquito’
  4. It is also called as ‘Nuisance mosquito’.

choices.text: a, b and c are correct

questions.solution:
The image given shows Aedes mosquito.

  • They do not fly over long distances, usually less than 100 metres(110 yards).
  • The eggs are laid singly and are Cigar-shaped.
  • Larvae are suspended with head downwards at an angle to the water surface, siphon tube is present, No palmate hairs.
  • Adults when at rest, exhibit hunch back, wings are unspotted.
  • They are referred to as ‘Tiger mosquito’ due to the stripes or bands on the legs.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

Characteristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia

Eggs: 100-250. 

 Laid singly. Boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star-shaped clusters.

Larval stage

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to the undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Striped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artificial collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis, Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 

Called Nuisance mosquitoes

These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called tiger mosquitoes

Day biters

They get the tiger's name from the white stripes on its legs.

 Big, black, or brown mosquitoes with sparkling wings and legs. 

 

 

Culex mosquito keeps their bodies horizontal while feeding.

 Anopheles mosquito tends to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high.

Aedes mosquito has a striped body pattern.

questions.text:
Consider the following statements regarding the Ziehl-Neelsen staining technique:

i. Flood with carbol fuchsin.
ii. Wash with distilled water.
iii. Flood slides with 3% acid-alcohol.
iv. Let stand for 2-3 min.
v. Heat the slide to steaming with the flame from a Bunsen burner.
vi. Allow slides to air dry.
vii. Flood the slides with methylene blue.


The correct sequence is:

choices.text: iii, ii, i, iv, v, vi, vii
i, v, ii, iii, iv, vii, vi
vii, ii, v, i, vi, iii, iv
ii, i, iv, v, vi, iii, vii

questions.solution:
The correct sequence of Ziehl-Neelsen (ZN) staining is as follows:

  1. Place slides on staining rack so they are at least 1 cm apart, and flood with carbol fuchsin.
  2. Heat the slide to steaming with the flame from a Bunsen burner. Do not let the stain boil or dry. Add additional stain if necessary.
  3. Wash off the stain with distilled water.
  4. Flood slides with 3% acid-alcohol.
  5. Let stand for 2-3 min (more acid-alcohol should be used if the smear is heavily stained).
  6. Wash off the acid-alcohol with distilled water and tilt the slides to drain.
  7. Flood the slides with methylene blue and let stand for 1-2 minute.
  8. Wash off the methylene blue with distilled water.
  9. Tilt the slides to drain.
  10. Allow slides to air dry in the slide rack. Do not blot.

 

Note: Recently, the World Health Organization (WHO), the International Union Against Tuberculosis and Lung Disease (The Union) and partners revised the recommended concentration of carbol fuchsin to 1% instead of 0.3%.

questions.text: A 30year old male had a road traffic accident was brought to the ER. The patient was stable and the clinical examination shows enophthalmos and ecchymosis around the orbital region. The intern examined the patient fo ocular motility. Suddenly the patient started vomitting and lost consciousness. CT scan is given below what is the next step of managemnt?

choices.text: Forced duction test to be performed to confirm ocular

questions.solution:
The next step of management in this patient is an immediate exploration of the orbit.

The given clinical scenario suggests an oculocardiac reflex in a patient with an orbital fracture.

Orbital blow out fracture:

Isolated fracture of the orbital floor when a large blunt object strikes the globe is called blow out fracture. The orbital contents herniate through the antrum.

Clinical signs: Periocular swelling (early stage), Enophthalmos, ecchymosis and subconjunctival hemorrhage (later stages).

Investigation:

Waters view in x-ray shows a teardrop opacity.

CT scan is used for the confirmation of the diagnosis.

Treatment:

The initial management is to prevent further injury to the globe.

Indications of surgery:

  • Enophthalmos
  • Diplopia
  • Ocular motility disorder
  • Immediate repair: Oculocardiac reflex, significant enophthalmos
  • Delayed repair is done with 2 weeks

questions.text:
Match the lymph nodes and the structures that drain to it:
Column A Column B
Para-aortic lymph nodes Prostate
External iliac lymph nodes Distal anal canal
Deep inguinal lymph nodes Superior Bladder
Internal iliac lymph nodes Glans penis
  Testis
questions.solution:
1. The para-aortic lymph nodes drain the testis. Paraaortic lymph nodes are a group of lymph nodes that lie in front of the lumbar vertebrae near the aorta. These lymph nodes receive drainage from the gastrointestinal tract and the abdominal organs. Paraaortic lymph node group is divided into three subgroups: preaortic, retroaortic, and right and left lateral aortic.

  2. The external iliac lymph nodes drain the Superior Bladder.

  3. The deep inguinal lymph nodes drain the glans penis. Deep inguinal lymph nodes lie medial to the femoral vein under the cribriform fascia. The uppermost node is in the groin, under the inguinal ligament, and is called Cloquet's node. The deep inguinal lymph nodes drain superiorly to the external iliac lymph nodes, then to the pelvic lymph nodes and on to the paraaortic lymph nodes.

  4. Internal iliac lymph nodes drain the prostate. The internal iliac lymph nodes (or hypogastric) surround the internal iliac artery and its branches (the hypogastric vessels), and receive the lymphatics corresponding to the distribution of the branches of it, i.e., they receive lymphatics from all the pelvic viscera, from the deeper parts of the perineum, including the membranous and cavernous portions of the urethra, and from the buttock and back of the thigh.

Related Pearl: Lymphatic drainage of pelvic structures

LYMPH NODES STRUCTURES DRAINING
Para - aortic lymph nodes Ovaries /Testis
External iliac lymph nodes Uterine body, cervix, superior bladder
Internal iliac lymph nodes Prostate, cervix, corpus cavernosum,proximal vagina
Superficial inguinal lymph nodes Distal vagina, vulva, scrotum, distal anal canal
Deep inguinal lymph nodes Glans penis

 

*Ref - Snells Clinical Anatomy - 4e

questions.text: A homeless malnourished chronic alcoholic with right lobar pneumonia undergoes a sputum examination which reveals partially acid fast bacilli with branching rods. Which of the the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Partially acid fast bacilli with branching rods suggest Nocardia. 

Infections caused by Nocardia can occur in immunocompetent and immunocompromised individuals.

Nocardia cause three types of skin infections in immunocompetent individuals:

• Mycetoma, a chronic, localized, painless, subcutaneous infection

• Lymphocutaneous infections

• Skin abscesses or cellulitis

In immunocompromised individuals, Nocardia can cause invasive pulmonary infections and disseminated infections.

Patients usually appear systemically ill, with fever, night sweats, weight loss, and a productive cough that may be bloody. Pulmonary infection can lead to complications such as pleural effusions, empyema, mediastinitis, and soft tissue infection.

An acute inflammatory response follows infection, resulting in necrosis and abscess formation. Granulomas are not usually formed.

Mycobacteria are acid fast bacilli but without branching rods.

questions.text: True statement about log roll technique is all except:

choices.text: Total number of personnel for a proper log roll technique is 4
In case of limb fracture then a 5 member log roll technique is followed
As the patient is rolled 2 people maintain the alignment of spine
During this technique one person stands at the head end of the patient and maintain the alignment of head and spine

questions.solution:
In a log roll technique 3 people maintain the allignment of spine as the patient is rolled.

LOG ROLL TECHNIQUE:

  • This maneuver is peformed to evaluate the patients spine and remove the long spineboard while limiting the spinal movement.
  • Atleast 4 people are needed for this maneuver.
  • One person stands at the patients head to control the head and c-spine and 2 are along the patients side to control the body and extremities.
  • The fourth person removes the board and examines the back.
  • Once the board is removed, 3 people return the patient to the supine position while maintaining the allignment of the spine

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding the given statements:

Assertion: Sacubitril/Valsartan is indicated in the treatment of NYHA class II to IV in heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.      

Reason: Sacubitril/Valsartan is an angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI) counteracts RAAS system and raises the level of vasoactive peptides.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true, the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true but the reason is not a correct explain the assertion
Assertion is true but the reason is false
Assertion is false but the reason is true

questions.solution:
Sacubitril(neprilysin inhibitor)-Valsartan(ARB) is known as ARNI (angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor).

It blocks the RAAS system while raising levels of endogenous vasoactive peptides(natriuretic peptides, bradykinin, adrenomedullin) degraded by neprilysin. (Reason)

It is indicated for use in patients with Chronic NYHA class II to class IV Heart failure (LVEF </= 40%) with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). (Assertion)

It reduces cardiovascular mortality and hospitalization for heart failure as well as all-cause mortality compared to ACE inhibitor alone.

questions.text: A patient with chronic hepatitis C presents with skin rash and joint pains for the past 10 days. He also gives a history of hematuria. Investigations show low C4 levels and positive rheumatoid factor. Which of the following will be abnormal in this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms, along with chronic hepatitis C, point to a diagnosis of cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. Serum cryoglobulin levels will be abnormal in this condition.

Cryoglobulins are immunoglobulins that precipitate in colder temperatures, leading to a vasculitis syndrome called cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. This syndrome is strongly associated with hepatitis C infection and occurs due to an aberrant immune response to hepatitis C antigens.

Patients present with cutaneous vasculitis, arthritis, and glomerulonephritis. Laboratory findings show circulating cryoprecipitates. Rheumatoid factor is positive in most patients, and complement levels are low.  

Other options:

Option A: ANCA antibodies are positive in granulomatous vasculitis like granulomatosis with polyangiitis(Wegener's syndrome) and Churg-Strauss syndrome.

Option C: Anti-CCP antibodies are positive in cases of rheumatoid arthritis.

Option D: Anti-dsDNA antibodies are positive in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

questions.text: The following are true about confidence interval except:

choices.text: The intervals are smaller with smaller sample size
95% of confidence interval means that 95% of all observed values in population fall within that interval
The width of the interval of the confidence interval will decrease in proportion to the square root of the sample size

questions.solution:
The intervals are smaller with smaller sample size is the incorrect statement. The confidence interval is smaller with a larger sample size. Standard error=SD/√ n. So Standard error will reduce when the population size is increased.

A 95% confidence interval means that 95% of all observed values in the population fall within that interval (Option B). It is calculated as follows:

Confidence interval = Mean ± 2 (Standard error) 

The confidence interval can be decreased by decreasing the standard error. Since Standard error = Standard deviation/√ n where n represents the sample size, an increase in sample size will decrease the standard error. But this decrease will be proportional to the square root of the sample size (Option C) as per the formula. Thus in order to reduce the confidence interval into half the sample size must increase fourfold. 

Smaller sample sizes will have larger standard errors and thus, larger confidence intervals. (Option A)

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding the given statements:

Assertion: In a case of primary hyperaldosteronism, returning of sodium and water excretion to normal by the kidneys is called aldosterone escape.

Reason: The aldosterone receptors get saturated in days resulting in a decreased effect of aldosterone in absorbing sodium by the kidneys.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true, the reason is the correct explanation of assertion
Both assertion and reason are true but the reason is not a correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is true but the reason is false
Assertion is false but the reason is true

questions.solution:
In a case of primary hyperaldosteronism, initially, aldosterone causes increased absorption of sodium by the kidneys. And along with the sodium, water is also absorbed resulting in increased blood pressure.

This rise in BP causes forced diuresis of both sodium and water, resulting in normalization of sodium and water excretion by the kidneys and the phenomenon is called aldosterone escape.

questions.text: The time interval between the receipt of infection by a host and maximal infectivity of that host is known as ______
questions.solution:
The time interval between the receipt of infection by a host and the maximal infectivity of that host is known as the generation time.

The time of maximum communicability may precede or follow the incubation period. In the case of mumps, the maximum communicability appears to reach its height about 48 hours before the onset of swelling of the salivary glands.

Option A: Lead time is the period between the first possible time of detection and the usual time of diagnosis.

Option B: Serial interval is the gap in time between the onset of the primary case and the second case. The term serial interval is used in an outbreak of disease.

Option D: Screening time is the time difference between the first point of diagnosis and the critical point of diagnosis. Screening must be done in conditions where there is a considerable time lag between the onset of disease and the usual time of diagnosis.

Related Pearl: Lead Time in Screening

Lead time is the period between the first possible time of detection and the usual time of diagnosis.

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening. It helps in the early diagnosis and treatment of disease. Early treatment reduces the severity by reversing the disease process.

questions.text: A 55 kg lady has a resting oxygen consumption of 240 ml/min with 0.25 ml O2/ml of systemic arterial oxygen content and systemic mixed venous content of 0.20 ml O2/ml. Her baseline heart rate is 70 beats/min. Her cardiac output and stroke volume respectively will be:
questions.solution:
Based on the Fick principle, cardiac output can be calculated by the following equation:

Cardiac output = Oxygen consumption / [O2] pulmonary vein - [O2] pulmonary artery

In the given scenario:

  • The oxygen consumption for the whole body at rest is 240 mL/min.
  • Pulmonary vein oxygen content is measured in systemic arterial blood, which is 0.25 mL/min
  • Pulmonary artery oxygen content is measured in systemic venous blood, which is 0.20 mL/min

Hence Cardiac output = 240 ml/min / 0.25-0.20

                                = 4800 ml/min or 4.8L/min

Stroke volume = Cardiac output/Heart rate

                                          = 4800 ml/min/70 beats/min

                                          = 68.5 ml/beat

questions.text: According to the Maternity Act, 2017 what is the duration of paid leave for a mother who is adopting a child?
questions.solution:
A mother who is adopting a child will be given a paid leave for a duration of 12 weeks.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

questions.text: A public health worker was brought with multiple transdermal dog bites. He tells you that he had received pre-exposure prophylaxis 6 months ago. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Wound washing and ARV with half dose of RIG
Wound treatment and ARV; RIG is not required

questions.solution:
This given clinical scenario of a patient with multiple transdermal dog bites would be categorised under category III. As the patient received pre-exposure prophylaxis 6 months ago, his line of management includes the following:
  1. Wound treatment with soap and running water for 15 minutes and application of antiseptic
  2. Anti-rabies vaccine 2 doses on day 0 and day 3, with either intradermal vaccine(0.1ml, 1 site) or intramuscular vaccine(1 vial, 1site).
There is no requirement for Rabies Immunoglobulin (RIG), if previous pre-exposure prophylaxis or post exposure prophylaxis documentation is available. If documentation of PEP or PrEP is unavailable, patient should be treated as fresh case and given full PEP.

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of 3 intramuscular (IM) or 3 intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text: The correct order of appearance of rigor mortis is.

choices.text: Chest, abdomen, fingers, upper extremity, legs
Upper extremity, chest, abdomen, fingers, legs
Chest, upper extremity, abdomen, legs, fingers
Upper extremity, chest, abdomen, legs, fingers

questions.solution:
The basic sequence of the rigor mortis begins from the head down the body, in the order of chest, upper extremity, abdomen, legs, and fingers. It disappears in the same order of appearance.

The left chamber of the heart is affected first. Other muscles are affected in the given order:

  1. Involuntary muscles: Heart
  2. Eyelids
  3. Neck and lower jaw
  4. Face
  5. chest
  6. Upper extremities
  7. Abdomen
  8. Legs
  9. Fingers and toes

Nysten's rule describes the sequential onset of rigor mortis in the various muscle groups.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old alcoholic presents to your OPD with fissuring of the lips, cracking at angles of the mouth, red eyes, and oily scaly rash on the scalp. Among the following co-factors of enzyme complexes, which one is most affected?

NAD: Nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide

TPP: Thiamine pyrophosphate

FAD: Flavin-adenine-dinucleotide
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency. FAD and FMN are the coenzymes of riboflavin; hence, the most co-factor affected in this scenario is FAD.

Riboflavin, or vitamin B2, deficiency manifests as angular stomatitis, magenta tongue, seborrhea, and corneal vascularization. It is seen in alcoholism, and individuals with a poor diet and decreased intake of dairy products.

Other options:

Option A: NAD+ is the coenzyme of vitamin B3 (nicotinic acid, niacin)

questions.text: All of the following lysosomal storage diseases are inherited in autosomal recessive fashion except:
questions.solution:
Fabry disease is inherited in an X-linked recessive manner.

It is due to a deficiency of alpha-galactosidase A and leads to accumulation of ceramide trihexoside.

The early presentation includes a triad of episodic peripheral neuropathy, angiokeratomas, and hypohidrosis. Eventually, patients develop progressive renal failure and cardiovascular disease.

questions.text: A drug has a volume of distribution of 50 L and undergoes zero-order elimination at a rate of 2 mg/hour at plasma concentrations 2 mg/L. If a patient is brought to the ER with a plasma concentration of 4 mg/L of the drug, how long will it take (in hours) for the plasma concentration to decrease 50%?
questions.solution:
Amount of drug in the body when plasma concentration is 4mg/L can be calculated by:

Amount of drug =Volume of distribution x plasma concentration

Amount of drug= 50 x 4= 200mg.

When plasma concertation falls to 2mg/L, body will contain 100mg of the drug (50L x 2mg/L= 100mg).

As mentioned in the question, body eliminates the drug at 2mg/hr when plasma concentration falls to 2mg/L. Hence, it will require 50 hours for 100mg of the drug to be eliminated.

questions.text: 1.	Regarding SMILE, identify the correct statement
questions.solution:
SMILE (small incision lenticule extraction) is a laser refractive surgery.

It is modified form of FLEx (femtosecond lenticule extraction) where instead of raising a flap lenticule is removed through a small incision. It is performed using femtosecond laser.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with an acute onset of blurry vision in the right eye. She had a sinus infection 2 weeks ago. She further recalls that 6 years ago, she had unilateral hemibody paraesthesias for a few weeks during her school examinations. Similar symptoms get triggered when she is overly tired. What is the immediate management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with an acute relapse of multiple sclerosis and methylprednisolone is used for immediate management.

The patient’s history of multiple clinically distinct episodes of central nervous system dysfunction exaggerated during times of stress and spontaneous partial resolution of the symptoms are highly suggestive of multiple sclerosis.

The patients' symptoms of blurry vision and pain on movement of the eye are suggestive of optic neuritis.

High dose intravenous methylprednisolone 1000 mg daily for five days without an oral taper is the drug of choice for acute exacerbation of multiple sclerosis.

Plasma exchange (Option B)can be used for an acute relapse of multiple sclerosis but is not the first preferred treatment. It can used along with steroids or in case of poor response to steroids. Beta interferon (Option C) is effective in the treatment of MS. But they are used for relapsing-remitting type MS.

Acyclovir (Option D) is not effective in the treatment of Acute MS. It can be used for the viral causes of optic neuritis.

2017 revised, McDonald’s criteria is used in the diagnosis of multiple sclerosis. The McDonald’s criteria takes into consideration the clinical attacks and objective lesions. In addition, it also involves an assessment of the lesions based on MRI and other imaging techniques.

questions.text: True statement about e-FAST is:

choices.text: It is useful in accurately detecting <100ml of free fluid in abdomen or pericardium
It is useful in determining the nature of the injury
It is not reliable for the assessment of the retroperitoneum
If the injury cannot be identified by e-FAST, then the test cannot be repeated

questions.solution:
e-FAST is not reliable for the assessment of the retroperitoneum.

e-FAST is used to assess the presence of free fluid in the abdominal cavity, thoracic cavity, and pericardium.

UTILISATION OF e-FAST:

  • It is not reliable in detecting less than 100 mL of free blood.
  • Does not directly identify injury to hollow viscus.
  • It cannot reliably exclude injury in penetrating trauma.
  • It is unreliable for the assessment of the retroperitoneum.

If there is a doubt, eFAST may be repeated or supplemented with other investigations.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with AIDS who was doing well until this morning started punching in the air, grabbing at insects and feeling of bugs crawling under the skin. Patients CD4 count was 95 cells/mm3 and temperature of 102.5 F. which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Acute onset symptoms of visual hallucination and altered sensorium in the setting of meningitis is indicative of delirium.

Psychotic disorders cannot be diagnosed if the symptoms can be explained by an acute medical illness. AIDS dementia presents with gradually worsening cognitive functioning.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are false regarding the area marked by arrow in the image?

choices.text: Middle meningeal artery lies immediately beneath the bone
It is located 4 cm above midpoint of zygomatic arch
Fracture at this point leads to extradural hemorrhage

questions.solution:
Pterion represents junction of 4 bones: frontal, parietal, temporal and greater wing of sphenoid bone.

It is located approximately 4 cm above midpoint of zygomatic arch.

Centre of pterion is referred to as sylvian point and the bone is thinnest at this point.

Frontal branch of middle meningeal artery, vein and lateral sulcus of brain are situated immediately below this point. Pterion is one of the commonest site of fracture and leads to extradural hemorrhage because of injury to middle meningeal artery.

questions.text: The drug which is not used in asthmatic women during pregnancy is?
questions.solution:
PGF2 alpha is not used in asthmatic women during pregnancy.

The first line therapy for acute asthma includes:

  • Terbutaline, Albuterol, Isoetharine, Epinephrine, isoproterenol or metaproterenol. The drugs can be taken subcutaneously, orally or inhaled.
  • Inhaled corticosteroids, Nebulized anticholinergic drugs can be added for improved response.
  • IV magnesium sulfate is given in case of exacerbations. Oral prednisolone or IV methylprednisolone for 5-10 days is also given.

questions.text: Graph depicting left ventricle pressure-volume changes during the cardiac cycle is given below. Identify the point at which mitral valve opens:
questions.solution:
Mitral valve opens when the left ventricular pressure is less than that of left atrial pressure.

At point 4 aortic valve closes, isovolumetric relaxation phase starts and ends with opening of mitral valve at point 1.

questions.text: Immunohistochemical testing was performed on a biopsy sample taken from a patient with breast cancer. Which of the following subtypes indicates the best prognosis?
questions.solution:
The luminal A molecular subtype of breast cancer is associated with the best prognosis. 

The cells in breast cancer may overexpress estrogen receptors (ER), progesterone receptors (PR), human epidermal growth factor receptor 2/neu (HER2/neu), and androgen receptors (AR). Ki-67 mitotic index indicates the degree of mitosis or proliferation. 

Based on these factors, breast cancer is classified into 5 subtypes. These include: 

  • luminal A
  • luminal B
  • HER2/neu enriched
  • basal
  • normal-like group

The luminal A subtype is the most common. They are defined as hormone receptor-positive (ER-positive and/or PR-positive), HER2/neu negative, and low Ki67 by immunohistochemistry. These tumors have a low histological grade, low degree of nuclear pleomorphism, and low mitotic activity. They are associated with a good prognosis and a significantly lower relapse rate.

Almost all breast malignancies are adenocarcinomas and based on the expression of estrogen receptor and HER2 can be divided into three major biologic subgroups:

  • ER-positive HER2-negative tumors (50% to 65% of tumors) – range from well-differentiated cancers with low proliferative rates and few chromosomal changes to poorly differentiated cancers with high proliferative rates and large numbers of chromosomal rearrangements. All of these cancers express ER.
  • HER2-positive cancers - 10% to 20% of tumors, which may either be ER-positive or ER-negative.
  • ER-negative, HER2-negative carcinomas (triple-negative or basal-like)- are characterized by genomic instability, a high proliferative rate, and expression of many proteins typical of myoepithelial cells (e.g., basal keratins).

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding the given statements:

Assertion: About 10% of patients with sarcoidosis presents with hypercalcemia and or hypercalciuria along with suppressed PTH level.   

Reason: Granuloma converts 25-OH Vit D to 1,25-OH Vit D due to the increased presence of 1α hydroxylase enzyme.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true, the reason is the correct explanation of assertion
Both assertion and reason are true but the reason is not a correct explain the assertion
Assertion is true but the reason is false
Assertion is false but the reason is true

questions.solution:
Both assertion and reason are true, the reason is the correct explanation of assertion.

Hypercalcemia and or hypercalciuria occurs in 10% of patients with sarcoidosis. The elevated calcium level suppresses the PTH level.

The granulomas seen in sarcoidosis have increased the activity of 1α  hydroxylase enzyme which activated Vit D to its active form ie. 1,25 OH Vit D.

questions.text: In a patient with thrombocytopenia what is the target platelet count after transfusion to perform an invasive procedure?
questions.solution: In a patient with  thrombocytopenia, target platelet count after transfusion to perform an invasive procedure is 50,000/microL.

questions.text: Glaukomflecken is caused by
questions.solution:
Glaukomflecken is seen following ischemia.

They are gray white epithelia and anterior cortical opacities that occur following an episode of markedly elevated intraocular pressure, like acute angle closure glaucoma.

questions.text: The following statements are True/False regarding Fractures
questions.solution:
1. Monteggia Fracture is called as Treacherous Lesion because dislocation of the head of the radius is often missed by physicians, sometimes even by radiologists.
  2. Bado’s classification is employed in adults and John Wein’s classification in children to classify Monteggia Fractures.
  3. Essex-Lopresti fracture is a fracture of the radial head with injury to the distal radioulnar joint and tearing of the interosseous membrane proximally and the Mechanism of injury is a heavy fall on the outstretched hands.
  4. Smith’s fracture is called as Reverse Colles’ fracture.
  5. Rim fractures of the distal radius are called Barton’s fracture, dorsal or volar rim could be involved and based on that Barton’s fracture is classified into Dorsal and Volar Barton’s. Dorsal Barton’s is a variant of Colles’.

questions.text:
Theme and focus: Headache

Answer option list:

  1. Cluster headache
  2. Subarachnoid hemorrhage
  3. Giant cell arteritis
  4. Chronic sinusitis
  5. Migraine
  6. Tension headache
  7. Paroxysmal hemicrania

For each of the following patients as described in the scenarios below, identify the cause from the above answer option list:
questions.solution:
CASE 1: Based on the history of unilateral headache, associated with nausea and sensitivity to light points towards migraine headache.

 

CASE 2: The history of a localized severe headache which is periodical which lasts for a short duration in an adult male, the most probable diagnosis is a Cluster headache. 

In Cluster headache at least one of the daily attacks recurs at about the same hour each day for the duration of a cluster bout.

The pain is deep, usually retroorbital, often excruciating in intensity, nonfluctuating, and explosive in quality.

 

CASE 3: Based on the nature of headache which is acute and severe in nature and along with the finding of xanthochromia of the CSF, the diagnosis is Subarachnoid hemorrhage.

Excluding head trauma, the most common cause of SAH is rupture of a saccular aneurysm.

questions.text: A 60 year old diabetic patient is admitted in the intensive care unit for treatment of urinary tract infection. The urine culture shows an indentified candida species and it is irresponsive to treatment. The culture in CHROM agar gives the following growth. Name the false statement about the following.

choices.text: It can present as an asymptomatic colonisation.
Family members of patients infected with condition should be treated irrespectively.
This condition can be treated with echinocandins
Swab from bilateral axilla and groin are used to screen for this condition.

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario suggests that patient is suffering from candida auris infection.

Family members of patients infected with this condition need not be treated irrespectively.

CANDIA AURIS:

  • It’s a multi drug resistant fungal infection.
  • People who are already sick in the hospital with a complication is more prone for this infection. It is generally misidentified as other organism.
  • It can cause many different types of infection such as blood stream, wound and ear infection.
    Identification: Basically identified as other organisms.The appearance and color of C.auris colonies in culture cannot be use d as the only identification method.
    C.auris is a budding yeast which never forms short pseudo hyphae and does not form germ tubes. It grows well on CHROM agar. The colonies appear white, pink, purple or red.

TREATMENT:

ECHINOCANDINS  are the drug which can used against this condition.

questions.text:
Match the fracture and the most common associated nerve injury:
Column A Column B
Hook of hamate

Common peroneal nerve

 
Lunate dislocation

Sciatic nerve

 
Posterior hip dislocation

Radial nerve

 
Fracture neck of the fibula

Median nerve

 
  Deep branch of ulnar nerve
questions.solution:
1. Hook of hamate fracture is commonly associated with injury of the deep branch of ulnar nerve. Hook of hamate fracture is commonly seen in golf/ hockey or baseball bat injuries. Hypothenar pain and pain with activities requiring tight grip are the most common presenting symptoms.

  2. Lunate dislocation is commonly associated with median nerve injury. It is caused by high energy traumatic injuries especially when the wrist is extended and ulnarly deviated. Patients present with acute wrist swelling and pain.

  3. Posterior dislocation of the hip is commonly associated with sciatic nerve injury. It occurs when there is significant trauma commonly as in motor vehicle accidents when hip is flexed and there is backward push due to impact with the dashboard. Clinically the affected limb is shortened, adducted and internally rotated.

  4. Fracture of neck of the fibula is associated with common peroneal nerve injury. It occurs due to direct injury or indirect twisting injury of the lower limb. Since fibula is a non-weight bearing bone it can be managed non operatively

questions.text: The baby is in which station?
questions.solution:
The head of the fetus it at the level of ischial spines. So it is in station 0.

  • The fetal station, that is the level of the presenting fetal part in the birth canal, is described in relation to the ischial spines. These spines lie halfway between the pelvic inlet and the pelvic outlet. When the lowermost portion of the presenting fetal part is at the level of the ischial spines, it is designated to be in zero station.
  • As the presenting fetal part descends from the inlet toward the ischial spines the designation is -5,-4, -3,-2,-1 then 0 station.
  • Below the spines, the presenting part passes +1,+2,+3,+4,+5 stations. Station +5 corresponds to the fetal head is visible at the level of introitus.

questions.text: While performing a modified radical neck dissection, the surgeon preserves the structure marked below. Which of the following is supplied by this structure?
questions.solution:
The structure marked above is the spinal accessory nerve. The spinal accessory nerve enters the posterior triangle passing deep to the sternocleidomastoid muscle and runs in an oblique direction within the triangle to supply the trapezius.

Option A: Phrenic nerve is seen related to the anterior surface of scalenus anterior, and supplies the diaphragm. 

Option C: The greater auricular nerve supplies the skin over the angle of the jaw, skin over the mandible, and lower 1/3rd of the auricle, greater auricular nerve (C2,3). 

Option D: The suprascapular nerve (C5, C6) arises from the upper trunk of the brachial plexus. It supplies the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles

Clinical note:

There are three types of modified radical neck dissection (MRND). Structures preserved are:

  • MRND 1 - Only spinal accessory nerve 
  • MRND 2 - Accessory nerve and internal jugular vein
  • MRND 3 i.e., functional neck dissection - Accessory nerve, sternocleidomastoid, and internal jugular veins.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man comes to your OPD with double vision, hearing loss in left ear. On examination, you find left esotropia and facial palsy. Most likely location of the lesion is:
questions.solution:
Based on clinical history and examination, the CP angle is the most likely location of the lesion.

Compression of vestibulocochlear nerve and facial nerve causes hearing loss and facial palsy. Ophthalmic symptoms such as diplopia, blurred vision are related to the mass effect on adjacent cranial nerves.

Cavernous sinus pathology presents with involvement of cranial nerves 4,6,3 but doesn't involve cranial nerve 7 and 8.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male admitted to the ICU for acute exacerbation of COPD develops a sudden onset of palpitations. The following ECG changes are seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a COPD patient in ICU developing palpitations and the ECG showing narrow QRS complex (<0.12 s) tachycardia with more than three different P wave morphologies, points to the diagnosis of multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT).

Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is characterized by at least 3 distinct P wave morphologies (shown by arrows in the image) with rates typically between 100 and 150 beats/min.

It is usually encountered in patients with chronic pulmonary disease and acute illness. The clinical features are most commonly related to the underlying precipitating illness (COPD in this case). Unlike atrial fibrillation, there are clear isoelectric intervals between P waves.

Treating the underlying disease and correcting any metabolic abnormalities is the mainstay of treatment. Electrical cardioversion has no effect.

The calcium-channel blockers verapamil or diltiazem may slow the atrial and ventricular rate. MAT may respond to amiodarone, but long-term therapy with this agent is usually avoided due to its toxicities, particularly in pulmonary fibrosis.

questions.text:
In which of the following patients would a lower amount of inhalational anesthetic be administered?
  1. 59-year-old chronic alcoholic
  2. 22-year-old addicted to cocaine
  3. 26-year-old pregnant lady
  4. 6-month-old infant
  5. 33-year-old man with serum calcium 12.5mg/dL
questions.solution:
Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) decreases in pregnancy and hypercalcemia. Thus, these patients require a lower dose of inhalational anesthetic agents.

Chronic alcoholics, infants, and people with a history of cocaine abuse would require higher doses of anesthetic agents.

questions.text: Which of the following antimalarial drugs is a slow acting schizonticide?
questions.solution:
Pyrimethamine is a slow-acting schizonticide.

Female Anopheles mosquito inoculates Plasmodium species in the form of sporozoites into the human host during blood meal. Sporozoites migrate to the liver and mature into hepatic schizonts. Hepatic schizonts are released into the blood in the form of merozoites. Merozoites in the erythrocyte transform into ring form and erythrocytic schizonts. Some merozoites in the blood transform into gametocytes. 

Antimalarial drugs are classified based on their onset of action of schizonticidal function as below:

  • Fast onset of action 
    • Artemisinin derivatives like artemether , arteether and  artesunate are fastest acting
    • Chloroquine
  • Intermediate onset of action
    • Mefloquine
    • Quinine
    • Proguanil
    • Lumefantrine
  • Slow onset of action
    • Pyrimethamine
    • Sulfonamides
    • Tetracyclines
    • Clindamycin

questions.text: An adolescent girl complaints of dropping objects from hands precipitated during morning hours and exams. There is no history of loss of consciousness. One of her cousins has been diagnosed with epilepsy. EEG was suggestive of epileptic spikes. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes an adolescent girl with myoclonic jerks (a history of dropping objects) with preserved consciousness. This, along with abnormal EEG findings strongly suggests juvenile myoclonic epilepsy.

Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (Janz syndrome) is the most common generalized epilepsy in young adults. It starts in early adolescence with one or more of the following features: bilateral myoclonic jerks in the morning, causing patients to drop things, generalized tonic-clonic or clonic-tonic-clonic seizures upon awakening, and juvenile absence seizure.

Consciousness is usually preserved. Precipitating factors include sleep deprivation, alcohol, and photic stimulation. EEG shows 4 to 5Hz polyspike and slow wave discharges. A family history of epilepsy is often present. 

The treatment options for JME include sodium valproate, levetiracetam, and topiramate. Benzodiazepine, lamotrigine, perampanel, phenobarbital, primidone, and zonisamide can be considered as add-on drugs. Complete remission is uncommon and has a high risk of seizure recurrence, hence antiepileptics are continued lifelong in a majority of the patients. 

Other options: 

Option B: Atypical absence seizures have been associated with myoclonic components and head drop. They are precipitated by drowsiness and EEG shows 1 to 2 Hz spike and slow wave discharges. 

Option D: In benign childhood epilepsy with centrotemporal spikes, the child typically wakes at night due to a focal seizure with preserved awareness. Buccal and throat tingling and tonic or clonic contractions on one side of the face are seen, with drooling and preserved consciousness. EEG shows typical wide-based centrotemporal spikes.

questions.text: As an intern in ICU, you decide to insert central venous catheter through femoral vein in a burns victim in order to administer intravenous fluids. Which of the following statements is not true?

choices.text: Needle is inserted medial to femoral artery
Femoral vein is located lateral to femoral artery
Femoral nerve is outside femoral canal

questions.solution:
The femoral vein is located medially to the femoral artery in the femoral sheath.

  • The femoral nerve is outside the femoral sheath and is lateral to the femoral artery.
  • It is important for the patient to be supine in order to maintain the femoral vessels in place during the procedure.
  • The femoral artery is palpated and the needle is inserted medial to it and directed towards umbilicus.

questions.text:
Match the drug with its most likely mechanism of resistance:
Column A Column B
Vancomycin Chromosome-encoded mutation in DNA gyrase, plasmid-mediated resistance
Aminoglycosides Decrease uptake or increase efflux out of bacterial cells by plasmid-encoded transport pumps
Tetracycline Bacterial transferase enzymes inactivate the drug by acetylation
Isoniazid Amino acid modification
  Mutation leading to under expression of KatG
  Mutation reduce drug binding to RNA polymerase
questions.solution:
A. Vancomycin resistance occurs in bacteria via amino acid modification of D-Ala-D-Ala to D-Ala-D-Lac.

B. Bacterial transferase enzymes inactivate Aminoglycosides by acetylation. Enzymatic modification of the aminoglycosides, mediated by aminoglycoside acetyltransferases, nucleotidyltransferases, or phosphotransferases is the most common mechanism of
resistance.

C. Resistance to Tetracyclines is by decreased uptake or increased efflux out of bacterial cells by plasmid encoded transport pumps.

D. Mechanism of resistance to Isoniazid is by Mutation leading to under expression of KatG. Resistance to fluoroquinolones is by chromosome-encoded mutation in DNA gyrase, plasmid mediated resistance.

Resistance to Rifampin and rifabutin is by mutations that reduce drug binding to RNA polymerase.

questions.text: The false statement among the following is:

choices.text: Gamma ray and X-ray are form of electromagnetic radiation
Beta emission from I-131 is used in its therapeutic purpose
Tc-99m is the most common radionuclide used for imaging
Beta emission from Tc-99 is used in its imaging purpose

questions.solution:
Gamma emission from Tc-99m is used in its imaging purpose.

  • Both gamma-ray and X-ray are electromagnetic radiation.
  • Gamma rays are emitted by an atomic nucleus in an excited state, whereas X-ray is the result of changes involving electrons.
  • I-131 emits beta rays and produce gamma photons during the course of decay.The beta ray is used primarily for therapy while the gamma ray is used for imaging.

questions.text: Choose the correct/wrong options pertaining to Lysosomal storage disorders
questions.solution:
1. Tay-Sachs disease is the most common form of GM2 gangliosidosis, resulting from mutations in the α-subunit locus on chromosome 15 that causes a severe deficiency of hexosaminidase A which is coded by HEXA gene.
  2. Niemann-Pick disease types A and B are two related disorders that are characterized by lysosomal accumulation of sphingomyelin due to an inherited deficiency of sphingomyelinase. Type A is a severe infantile form with extensive neurologic involvement, marked visceral.
    Accumulations of sphingomyelin, and progressive wasting and early death within the first 3 years of life.
    In contrast, type B disease patients have organomegaly but generally no central nervous system involvement. They usually survive into adulthood.
  3. Gene mutations in HEXB gene located on chromosome 5 often result in Sandhoff disease.
  4. Gaucher disease results from lack of the lysosomal enzyme glucocerebrosidase and accumulation of glucocerebroside in mononuclear phagocytic cells. In Type I variant, which is the most common variant affected phagocytes become enlarged (Gaucher cells) and accumulate in liver, spleen, and bone marrow, causing hepatosplenomegaly and bone erosion. Types II and III are characterized by variable neuronal involvement.
  5. All the Mucopolysaccharidoses are inherited as Autosomal recessive traits except Hunter syndrome which is inherited as an X linked recessive trait.

questions.text: How is an electrical synapse different from a chemical synapse?

choices.text: No cytoplasmic continuity between presynaptic and postsynaptic membrane
Connexons are involved in electrical synapse
Electrical synapse has more latent period than chemical synapse

questions.solution:
In electrical synapses, the cytoplasm of adjacent cells is directly connected by gap junctions (connexons) that allow free movement of ions from the interior of one cell to the interior of the next cell.

The transmis­sion in electrical synapses is bidirectional and there is no synaptic delay. Unlike chemical synapses, electrical synapse has cytoplasmic continuity.

Note:  

Most of the synapses used for signal transmission in the central nervous system are chemical synapses.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male patient came with complaints of swelling of ankle for the past 3 months. Urine examination shows heavy proteinuria. Blood examination reveals hypoalbuminemia and hypercholesterolemia. He is an HBsAg positive patient. True statement about his condition is:

choices.text: The condition is most commonly seen in females
Electron microscopy reveals endothelial immune complex deposition
The antibodies are produced against N-type phospholipase A2 receptor
The condition is associated with selective proteinuria

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests nephrotic syndrome. The antibodies are produced against N-type phospholipase A2 receptor in secondary membranous glomerulonephritis.

Membranous glomerulonephritis is seen in ~20 % of adults with a peak incidence between 30-50 years of age.

The primary type is associated with antibodies developed against the M-type phospholipase A2 receptor.

Secondary type is associated with Hepatitis B, breast carcinoma, syphilis, malaria and rheumatologic disorders like lupus, rheumatoid arthritis.

Pathological findings:

  • Light microscopy: Uniform thickening of the basement membrane along the peripheral capillary loops
  • Immunofluorescence: Diffuse granular deposits of IgG and c3.
  • Electron microscopy: Dense subepithelial deposits.

questions.text: A baby in the NICU is being evaluated for his features of microcephaly and hepatomegaly. CT scan revealed nodular periventricular calcifications. Congenital CMV infection is suspected. Which of the following samples is the best to detect the organism using PCR?
questions.solution:
Among the following options, urine is the best sample to be sent for the diagnosis of congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. 

In congenital CMV infections, the investigation of choice is PCR or viral culture. It should be done within the first three weeks of life (after this period, it is difficult to distinguish between a congenital and an acquired infection). Since not all affected infants are viremic at birth, urine is a more reliable sample than blood. 

Most CMV transmission occurs in the first trimester. The risk of transmission is high in the third trimester. 90% of the infected babies are asymptomatic and have lesser chances of having late sequelae. 

The clinical manifestations include hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rashes, jaundice, chorioretinitis, and microcephaly. Neuroimaging shows intracranial periventricular calcifications. One of the long-term sequelae is sensorineural hearing loss.

There is no definitive treatment for congenital CMV infection. Treatment with ganciclovir is indicated only in patients with progressive neurologic disease and deafness.

The image below shows periventricular calcifications:

questions.text: The following factors define an infant as being high risk:
A patient in low output cardiogenic shock is being treated with dobutamine. Which of the following is true about the drug?

choices.text: Acts on D1 and D2 receptors
Has no effect on coronary circulation

questions.solution:
Dobutamine decreases peripheral resistance minimally.

Clinically, dobutamine increases cardiac output by selectively increasing myocardial contractility and promotes coronary vasodilation. This is associated with a mild decrease in total peripheral vascular resistance, which is mediated by the reflex withdrawal of sympathetic tone to the vasculature.

Dobutamine has a t1/2 of 2 minutes. It resembles dopamine but no action is seen on dopamine receptors.

Renal circulation is variably affected depending upon the sympathetic tone of the patient.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely thyroid pathology depicted in the radioactive testing scan below?
questions.solution:
The scan findings are suggestive of thyroid cancer.

The radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) scan shows negligible tracer uptake in the left lower lobe. This is suggestive of cold nodule. The most common cause of cold nodule in an RAIU scan is thyroid cancer.

Thyroiditis: The RAIU will show decreased radioiodine uptake though uniformly.

Grave’s disease: The RAIU will show generalized increased uptake uniformly throughout the thyroid.

Thyroid adenoma: The RAIU will show localized nodule with increased uptake of radioiodine.

questions.text: In the following oxygen-dissociation curve, which curve indicates poisoning with carbon monoxide?
questions.solution:
Curve C indicates poisoning with carbon monoxide (CO).

CO binds to hemoglobin and prevents O2 binding (therefore the decrease in the Vmax). 

CO binds to hemoglobin with an affinity that is 250 times that of O2 to form carboxyhemoglobin. This means that when the partial pressure of CO is only 1/250 that of O2, equal amounts of CO and O2 will bind to hemoglobin. Thus, the hemoglobin that can now bind to O2 is reduced to 50% causing a reduction in the graph's height.

CO also increases the O2 affinity of remaining free hemoglobin sites which causes a left shift of the O2 - hemoglobin dissociation curve.

Curve A - Myoglobin O2-dissociation curve (Myoglobin has a higher affinity towards O2 than hemoglobin. Hence, it shows a hyperbolic curve with a left shift)

Curve B - Normal Hb O2-dissociation curve 

Curve D - Curve showing anemia

The increased affinity of hemoglobin for O2 following CO binding is explained by the co-operative binding phenomenon.

questions.solution:

questions.text: An elderly man is diagnosed with a slow-growing tumor in the deep perineal pouch. Which of the following structure would be most likely affected?
questions.solution:
A tumor in the deep perineal space is most likely to affect the bulbourethral glands as they are present in the deep perineal pouch.

Contents of deep perineal pouch:

  • Membranous urethra
  • Muscles: Sphincter urethrae and deep transverse perinei muscles
  • Nerves: Dorsal nerve of penis and muscular branches of the perineal nerve
  • Vessels: Artery of penis
  • Glands: Bulbourethral glands in males

Contents of superficial perineal pouch: 

  • Corpora cavernosa and corpus spongiosum
  • Three muscles – the ischiocavernosus, bulbospongiosus and superficial transverse perineal
  • The greater vestibular glands (Bartholin’s glands) in females and duct of bulbourethral glands in males.
  • Arteries: Branches of the perineal artery (posterior scrotal and transverse perineal arteries) and branches of artery of the penis (artery to the bulb, urethral artery, deep artery of the penis and dorsal artery of the penis)
  • Nerves: Long perineal nerve, branches of the perineal nerve (posterior scrotal, nerve to bulb and muscular branches)
  • Clitoris in female
  • Urethra in male

questions.text: The following are slides showing the immunohistochemistry of Her 2 Neu expression. Lapatinib will be effective in which of the following :
questions.solution:
Lapatinib is the targeted therapy for Her-2 positive cases. Among the following slides it will be effective in slide B and C.

Her-2 Neu positive tumors are :

Tumors that show 3+ staining on IHC (here FISH is not necessary)

Tumors that show 2+ staining on IHC and Her 2 Neu gene amplification detected by In situ hybridization.

questions.text: The following statements are True/False in relation to Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971
questions.solution:
1. Pregnancy caused by Rape is terminated under the purview of Humanitarian indications.
    Social indication includes pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives.
  2. A registered medical practitioner can qualify to terminate a pregnancy if he/she has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of M.T.P. in a recognised hospital.
  3. MTP Amendment Bill, 2014 considers allowing Homeopathy and Ayurveda practitioners to conduct M.T.P
  4. It is enough for the woman to state that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.
  5. Consent of the Husband is not necessary.

Related Pearl: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act with 2021 amendments 

Indications:

  • Therapeutic - to save the life of the mother
  • Eugenic - to prevent the risk of the child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality i.e. first-trimester viral infections, teratogenic drug intake, radiation exposure
  • Humanitarian - pregnancy resulted from rape or incest
  • Social - pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives 

Rules:

  • Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.
  • MTP should be carried out in a government or government-recognized hospital. Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.
  • The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years. 

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

  • Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion
  • 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Upper limit of MTP:

  • Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations
  • Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)
  • At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Confidentiality:

A register for recording the details of MTP must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used. Unlawful disclosure of patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine.

questions.text: Which among the following layer has abundant desmosomes ?
questions.solution:
Stratum spinosum or prickle cell layer contains abundant desmosomes.

The image showing layers of the epidermis, it is divided from deep to superficial as 

  • Stratum basale (Basal layer)
  • Stratum spinosum (Spinous or prickle cell layer)
  • Stratum granulosum (Granular layer)
  • Stratum lucidum (Clear layer)
  • Stratum corneum (Cornified layer)

Stratum spinosum- contain several layers of closely packed keratinocytes that interdigitate with each other by means of numerous cell surface projections. These cells are anchored to each other by desmosomes that provide tensile strength and cohesion to the layer. when the skin is seen under light microscopy, the cell tend to shrink away except where they are joined by desmosomes, giving them spiny appearance. 

 

Desmosomes:

They are the major intercellular junctions in the skin which join the adjacent keratinocytes.

They contain 3 proteins inside called as Desmoglein(dsg), Desmocollin and Desmoplakin.

Desmocollin

Note: If the question was asked about the location of Hemi-desmosomes, then the answer will be : Between stratum basale and dermo-epidermal junction.

questions.text:
Arrange the sequence of steps in leukocyte migration:

a.Stable adhesion
b.Integrin activation by chemokine
c.Rolling
d.Migration through endothelium
questions.solution:
The journey of leukocytes from the vessel lumen to the tissue is a multistep process that is mediated and controlled by adhesion molecules and cytokines called chemokines.

This process can be divided into sequential phases :

  1. In the lumen:
    • Margination
    • Rolling (selectin-mediated)
    • Activation of integrins (cytokine-mediated)
    • Adhesion (integrin-mediated) to the endothelium

Vascular endothelium in its normal, unactivated state does not bind circulating cells or impede their passage. In inflammation, the endothelium is activated and can bind leukocytes.

    2. Migration across the endothelium and vessel wall: Diapedesis

    3. Migration in the tissues toward a chemotactic stimulus

questions.text: A 70-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with altered mental status. Lab workup shows serum sodium of 110 mEq/L and negative alcohol and toxicology screens. An opacity in the left lower lung is seen on the chest X-Ray. What is the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) with altered mental status, and the management in this patient is 3% saline.

SIADH occurs due to excessive production of ADH (or vasopressin). The most common cause are neuroendocrine neoplasms like small cell lung carcinoma (at least half the cases) and carcinoids.

Symptoms include decreased thirst, lethargy, nausea, confusion, depressed mental status, and seizures. However, most patients are asymptomatic and are diagnosed incidentally due to the presence of hyponatremia. The severity of symptoms indicates the severity of hyponatremia. Hyponatremia occurs with decreased serum osmolality and normal or increased urine osmolality.

Management includes correction of hyponatremia and treatment of the underlying malignancy. Since hyponatremia develops over several weeks to months, it should be corrected gradually at a rate of 0.5–1 meq/L/h to prevent brain dehydration and central pontine myelinolysis (an acute life-threatening neurological syndrome characterized by quadriparesis, ataxia, and abnormal extraocular movements).

  • Hypervolemic hyponatremia:
    • Fluid restriction to less than urine output, plus insensible losses, with strict monitoring of fluid intake in mild cases
    • Vasopressin receptor antagonists, like conivaptan and tolvaptan, in severe cases
  • Hypovolemic hyponatremia and/or altered mental status (indicating severe hyponatremia of <115 mEq/L): Hypertonic (3%) or isotonic saline infusion

Demeclocycline, an inhibitor of vasopressin, is not preferred due to its relatively slower onset of action (1–2 weeks).

Related Pearl: Causes of SIADH

Neoplasms

Carcinomas

  • Lung
  • Duodenum
  • Pancreas
  • Ovary
  • Bladder, ureter

Other neoplasms

  • Thymoma
  • Mesothelioma
  • Bronchial adenoma
  • Carcinoid
  • Gangliocytoma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma

Head trauma (closed and penetrating)

Infections

  • Pneumonia
  • Abscess
  • Cavitation (aspergillosis)

questions.text:
The correct sequence of events occurring during acute inflammation is:

i. Dilation of blood vessels.
ii. Emigration of leucocytes from the microcirculation.
iii. Increased permeability of the microvasculature.
iv. Accumulation of leukocytes in the focus of injury.
v. Increased blood flow.
vi. Activation of leukocytes.

choices.text: v, i, iii, vi, ii, iv
vi, v, i, iii, ii, iv
i, v, iii, ii, iv, vi
iii, v, i, ii, vi, iv

questions.solution:
The components of acute inflammation are as follows:

  • Dilation of small vessels, leading to increase in blood flow
  • Increased permeability of the microvasculature
  • Emigration of the leukocytes from the microcirculation
  • Accumulation of leukocytes in the focus of injury
  • Activation of leukocytes to eliminate the offending agent

The causes of inflammation include infections, tissue necrosis, foreign bodies, trauma, and immune responses.

The outcome of acute inflammation is either elimination of the noxious stimulus followed by decline of the reaction and repair of the damaged tissue, or persistent injury resulting in chronic inflammation.

questions.text: A 45 year old male came with complaints of epistaxis to the emergency department. His pulse rate was 84/min and BP is 110/70mmHg. He was pale and had multiple telengiectasias around his  lips. He has history of multiple epistaxis in the past for which he was treated conservatively. True statement regarding this condition is:

choices.text: Youngs procedure is the next step of management
Curacao criteria is used for the prognosis

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasias or Osler Weber Rendu disease.

Bevacizumab is used to treat this condition.

Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia:

  • The autosomal-dominant disorder that can be caused by mutations in at least five different genes, most of which modulate TGF-β signaling.
  • It is characterized by dilated, tortuous blood vessels with thin walls that bleed readily.
  • Bleeding can occur anywhere, but it is most common in the mucous membranes of the nose (epistaxis), tongue, mouth, and eyes, and throughout the gastrointestinal tract.
  • CURACAO CRITERIA is used in the diagnosis of this condition. It includes:
  • Spontaneous recurrent epistaxis
  • Multiple telangiectasias in typical locations (see above)
  • Proven visceral AVM (lung, liver, brain, spine)
  • A first-degree family member with HHT

Treatment:

Bevacizumab and beta blockers

questions.text: The following images show:
questions.solution:
The following image shows the Jersey finger and baseball finger.

  • Jersey finger - It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of distal phalanx with the ring finger most commonly involved.
  • Baseball finger: Mallet finger/baseball finger is a disruption to the extensor tendon of the little finger or thumb when the collision with a hard object (a ball) forces it to flex past its normal range of motion.

 

Related Pearl: Important Injuries of the Hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected.

questions.text: The ophthalmologic instrument shown in the image is not used for:
questions.solution:
The image shows a stenopaic slit. It is not used in corneal tattooing.

It can be used to: 

  • Determine the axis of the cylinder in astigmatism.
  • In cases with corneal opacity, the optimal site for optical iridectomy is determined using a stenopaic slit
  • Perform Fincham's Test

Related Pearl: Fincham’s Test

Also called Emsley–Fincham Test

It used for differentiating between the colored halos due to cataract (lenticular) and those in corneal edema due to glaucoma. It is performed by passing a stenopaic slit across the pupil and observing the halos.

Halos are broken up into segments which revolve as the slit moves → Lenticular halo

Intact halos but the intensity and brightness are diminished → Glaucomatous halo

The image shows a stenopaeic slit.

It causes reduced size of blur circle in the meridian perpendicular to the slit and no change in the blur circle in the meridian coincident with it. So, it can be used to determine the axis of the cylinder in astigmatism.

In cases with corneal opacity, the optimal site for optical iridectomy is determined using a stenopaic slit.

questions.text: Choose the correct/wrong statements with respect to the Mental Healthcare Act 2017
questions.solution:
1. “Care-giver” means a person who resides with a person with mental illness and is responsible for providing care to that person and includes a relative or any other person who performs this function, either free or with remuneration.
  2. Every person, who is not a minor, shall have a right to make an advance directive
  3. “Mental health professional” means
    (i) A psychiatrist
    (ii) A professional registered with the concerned State Authority
    (iii) A professional having a post-graduate degree (Ayurveda) in Mano
    Vigyan Avum Manas Roga or a post-graduate degree (Homoeopathy) in Psychiatry or a post-graduate degree (Unani) in Moalijat (Nafasiyatt) or a post-graduate degree (Siddha) in Sirappu Maruthuvam.
  4. Past treatment or hospitalisation in a mental health establishment though relevant, shall not by itself justify any present or future determination of the person’s mental illness.
  5. The medical practitioner or mental health professional shall not be held liable for not following a valid advance directive, if he has not been given a copy of the valid advance directive.

questions.text: La facies sympathique is seen in_____
questions.solution:
La facies sympathique indicates ante mortem hanging.

  • In case of hanging if the ligature knot presses on the cervical sympathetic chain, the eye on the same side may remain open and its pupil dilated (La facies sympathique).
  • Dribbling of saliva and intimal tears in carotid artery are two other features which indicate ante mortem hanging.

questions.solution: Neuropsychology examines the relationship between behavioral and brain functioning. It involves study of effects of illness and injuries on cognitive and behavioral functioning.

A cricothyrotomy is an incision made through the skin and cricothyroid membrane.

questions.text: A woman presents to the dermatology OPD with the following painful lesions that developed rapidly over the course of 3 weeks. She says that she has been undergoing leprosy treatment at her local PHC for the past 8 months. What form of leprosy is her condition most commonly associated with?
questions.solution:
Development of ulcerating lesions following initiation of treatment for leprosy is suggestive of a severe type 1 lepra reaction. They are commonly seen in the borderline spectrum but are most severe in borderline lepromatous leprosy.

Lepra 1 reactions are due to an enhanced cell-mediated immune response to M.leprae. They usually present abruptly with redness and inflammation of existing lesions but can cause ulceration in severe cases. It occurs due to a large amount of M. leprae antigens in these patients which results in prolonged and repeated reactions during treatment. 

Note: Another form of lepra reaction with ulcerating lesions is the Lucio reaction. It is a rare type of lepra reaction that is seen in patients with lepra bonita. It is often the initial presentation in untreated patients. It is common over extremities and spreads in an ascending fashion. It presents as tender nodules that form jagged ulcers.  

Related Pearl: Lepra Reactions

Mainly seen in the Borderline spectrum (BT, BB, BL)

Usually seen within 12 months of initiation of Multidrug Therapy

Due to enhanced cell-mediated response increased destruction of bacilli following treatment in reversal

Type 3 Hypersensitivity

Primarily Humoral

(Immune complex Deposition in tissues and vessels)

Cytokine involved - TNF-α

New lesions may occur (rare)

Neuritis and Nerve abscesses (red, painful inflamed nerves)

New, erythematous and tender, subcutaneous and dermal nodules that are widely distributed over extremities and face

Existing lesions do not change
No systemic involvement Systemic symptoms present - fever, myalgias, arthralgias, anorexia, keratitis, iritis, nephritis, synovitis, orchitis, lymphadenopathy

Treatment:

Supportive therapy for mild reactions with NSAIDs

In case of severe reactions with neuritis and eye lesions- Oral corticosteroids

(Drug of Choice)

Nerve Abscess - Additional surgical drainage

Other drugs: Clofazimine, Cyclosporine

Treatment:

Oral Corticosteroids - First-line drug

Clofazimine (Steroid dependent ENL)

questions.text: VDRL test for syphilis is a type of:
questions.solution:
VDRL test for syphilis is a type of precipitation reaction.

When a soluble antigen combines with its antibody in the presence of electrolytes at a suitable temperature and pH, the antigen-antibody complex forms an insoluble precipitate. This reaction is called precipitation reaction.

When these precipitates remains suspended as floccules it is called flocculation reaction. VDRL is a slide flocculation reaction.

questions.text: A 60 year old male comes to the clinic with symptoms of easy fatigue for a couple of months. Examination shows pale conjunctive and splenomegaly. A blood count was ordered and it shows: Hb 9g/dL, WBC 55,000/μL, platelets 83,000/μL. Which of the following is not true regarding this disease?

choices.text: With TKI therapy the estimated 10 year survival is only 50%
The t(9;22)(q34.1;q11.2) is present in more than 90% of cases
It has an early indolent phase followed by an accelerated phase and a terminal blastic phase
Splenomegaly is the most common clinical finding

questions.solution:
With TKI (Tyrosine kinase inhibitor) therapy the estimated 10-year survival is 85% and not 50%.

Based on the age and symptoms of anaemia and splenomegaly and highly elevated WBC count, the diagnosis is Chronic myeloid leukaemia. The other options are correct.

questions.text: Zero incidences of a specified disease in a defined geographical area refers to
questions.solution:
Zero incidences of a specified disease in a defined geographical area refers to elimination of a disease.

  • Elimination: Reduction to zero (or a very low defined target rate) of new cases of an infectious disease in a defined geographical area as a result of deliberate efforts; continued measures to prevent re-establishment of transmission are required.
  • Eradication: Complete and permanent worldwide reduction to zero new cases of an infectious disease through deliberate efforts; no further control measures are required.
