questions.text:
Match the condition with the anatomic structure affected:
Column A Column B
Tennis elbow Lateral epicondyle
Golfers elbow Medial epicondyle
Nursemaid's elbow Olecranon
Popeye's elbow Radial head
questions.solution:
1. Tennis elbow (lateral epicondylitis) involves the lateral epicondyle. It is caused by
    repetitive contraction of extensor muscles at lateral epicondyle—in activities that require
    repetitive forceful wrist extension and supination (backhand in tennis and use of
    screwdriver).
  2. Golfers elbow (Medial epicondylitis) involves the medial epicondyle. It is caused by
    repetitive contraction of flexor muscles at medial epicondyle. Pain can be elicited by
    resisted wrist flexion and passive wrist extension.
  3. Nursemaid’s Elbow (Radial head subluxation) involves the displacement of the radial
    head. It occurs when axial traction on a pronated forearm with the elbow in extension. This
    causes annular ligament to slip over the radial head and gets trapped in the radiohumeral
    joint.
  4. Popeye’s elbow (Olecranon bursitis) involves the olecranon bursa. It occurs most
    commonly because of trauma, sepsis and inflammatory arthritis.

questions.text: Climacteric is related to:
questions.solution:
Climacteric is the phase of waning ovarian activity, and may begin 2–3 years before menopause and continue for 2–5 years after it.

The climacteric is thus a phase of adjust­ment between the active and inactive ovarian function and occupies several years of a woman’s life, and it involves physical, sexual and psychological adjustments.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding the given statements?

Assertion: In a case of cardiac tamponade, there is greater than 10 mmHg fall of BP during inspiration.    

Reason: Due to increased pericardial pressure the interventricular septum bulges into the right ventricle.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true, the reason is the correct explanation of assertion
Both assertion and reason are true but the reason is not a correct explain the assertion
Assertion is true but the reason is false
Assertion is false but the reason is true

questions.solution:
The assertion is true but the reason is false as during inspiration the increased blood to the right ventricle causes in to expand.

And because of this reason, the interventricular septum bulges into the left ventricle and reduces its output causing fall in BP during inspiration.

questions.text: A blood cold chain involves:
questions.solution:
A simple blood cold chain involves Blood donor- VIP-refrigerator-patient.

VIP is a very important person responsible for blood storage. Break in the chain happens more commonly when the equipment does not meet the standards of quality and safety.

Major items in this chain include refrigerators, transport boxes, freezers, standby generators, and temperature monitors.

30-minute rule: It is a rule in blood banking stating that a maximum time of 30 minutes is allowed for a blood component issued from the blood bank to the ward to be returned.

questions.text: Optic nerve injury following sinus surgery (FESS) is due to removal of which of the following ethmoidal cells?
questions.solution:
Onodi cell is the posterior ethmoidal cell, related superiorly or laterally to the sphenoid sinus. The optic nerve lies in its lateral wall and can be injured while operating in the cells.

Option A: Haller cells are a type of ethmoidal cells that are situated on the roof of the maxillary sinus. Sometimes they may enlarge and block the opening of the maxillary sinus leading to maxillary sinusitis.

Option B: Agger nasi is an elevation just anterior to the attachment of middle turbinates.

Option D: Bulla ethmoidalis is the ethmoidal cell situated behind the uncinate process and forms the posterior boundary of hiatus semilunaris through which the maxillary, frontal and anterior ethmoidal sinuses drain.

questions.text: Artificial nose in an anesthesia machine is

choices.text: Controls of oxygen flow in the machine
An alternate route of ventilation when the endotracheal tube is blocked
Administration of drugs in case of emergency

questions.solution:
The artificial nose in the anesthesia machine is a heat and moisture exchanger.

  • It is attached between the tracheal tube and the right angle connector of the breathing circuit.
  • These are passive devices which do not add heat or vapor but contains hygroscopic material that traps exhaled humidification and heat which is released upon subsequent inhalation.

questions.text: Pembrolizumab is not approved for use in which of the following malignancies?
questions.solution:
Pembrolizumab is not approved for use in non-metastatic small-cell lung cancer. It is approved for metastatic small cell lung cancer (SCLC).

Pembrolizumab is a monoclonal antibody (IgG4) against PD-1 and blocks interaction between PD-1 and its ligands PD-L1 and PD-L2. It is used in the following conditions:

  • Metastatic SCLC 
  • Hodgkin’s lymphoma
  • Metastatic urothelial cancer
  • Metastatic non SCLC
  • Merkel cell carcinoma
  • Chemotherapy-refractory head and neck cancers
  • Refractory melanoma
  • Triple-Negative Breast Cancer
  • Esophageal Cancer
  • Colorectal cancer due to Lynch syndrome

questions.text: Full-term baby born to a 38-year-old lady has 5 digits on each hand and foot. Head circumference is less than 3rd centile, length and weight are in 50th centile. Ears are low set with flat pinnae and pointed upper helix. Image of hand is given below. Karyotype will show which of the following:
questions.solution:
The infant has low-set/malformed ears, abnormal clenched fingers, congenital heart defect, maternal age>35 years all suggestive of trisomy 18.

Classic signs include clenched hand and overlapping fingers and rocker bottom feet.

Trisomy 13 presents with microphthalmia, microcephaly, cleft lip/palate, polydactyly, congenital heart disease. Trisomy 21 presents with prominent epicanthal folds, simian crease, congenital heart disease.

questions.text:
Match the adult structure with the corresponding embryonic origin:
Column A Column B
Gartner duct Mesonephric duct
Round ligament Gubernaculum
Bartholin's glands Labioscrotal swelling
Glans clitoris Urogenital sinus
  Genitual tubercle
questions.solution:
1. Gartner's duct is an embryological remnant in human female development of the Mesonephric duct in the development of the urinary and reproductive organs. Gartner's duct is located in the uterine broad ligament.
  2. Round ligament develops from the Gubernaculum. The gubernaculum attaches the gonad to the labioscrotal swelling in the embryo. The function of the round ligament is the maintenance of the anteversion of the uterus.
  3. Bartholin’s glands develop from the Urogenital sinus. Bartholin’s glands are located posteriorly and either side of the vagina. They secrete mucus to lubricate the vagina. They are homologous to the bulbourethral glands in the males.
  4. Glans clitoris develops from the Genital tubercle. It is homologous to the penis in males.The labioscrotal swelling represent the final stage of development of the caudal end of theexternal genitals before sexual differentiation. In both males and females, the two swellings
    merge.

questions.text:
Match the following paraneoplastic condition with the most likely malignancy:
Column A Column B
Pityriasis rotunda Carcinoma Pancreas
Erythema gyratum repens Hepatocellular carcinoma
Migratory thrombophlebitis Lung cancer
Hypoglycaemia Mycosis fungoides
  Ovarian carcinoma
questions.solution:
1. Pityriasis rotunda is commonly associated with Hepatocellular carcinoma.
    • It is characterized by discrete, round, scaly, pigmented patches.

  2. Erythema gyratum repens is most frequently associated with lung cancer.
    • It is characterized by figurate erythema commonly with concentric erythematous bands forming a wood-grain appearance.

  3. Migratory thrombophlebitis, known as Trousseau's syndrome, occurs in about 10% of patients with pancreatic adenocarcinoma.
    • It is attributed to the production of platelet- aggregating factors and procoagulants from the tumour or its necrotic products. Both venous and arterial thrombi can occur. Venous thrombi can embolize to the lungs.

  4. Hypoglycemia commonly occurs with ovarian cancer.
    • In ovarian tumours, there is increased expression of GLUT1 which causes increased glucose uptake. This, in turn, causes hypoglycemia.
    • Insulin and insulin-like growth factors also play a role in causing hypoglycemia. 
  5. Mycosis fungoides is the most common form of cutaneous T cell lymphoma. The advanced stage of mycosis fungoides is characterized by generalized erythroderma and exfoliative dermatitis.

questions.text: The serum hormonal level seen on the day of ovulation are all except:
questions.solution:
The blood level of progesterone on the day of ovulation is decreased.

The mural granulosa cell before ovulation has receptors for LH and hence there is a small increase in progesterone level before ovulation. This small increase helps the estrogen in causing the LH surge. However after ovulation i.e at the day of ovulation, the oocyte lacks these LH receptors and hence there is no progesterone at this stage. Corpus luetum inturn serves as the source of progesterone after ovulation.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes do not contain selenocysteine at its active sites?
questions.solution:
Methyltransferase does not contain selenocysteine at its active sites.

Selenocysteine is present at the active site of several human enzymes that catalyze redox reactions.

Examples include:

  • Thioredoxin reductase
  • Glutathione peroxidase
  • Deiodinase
  • Selenoprotein P
  • Glycine reductase

questions.text: A 66-year-old man comes to the clinic complaining of shortness of breath during physical exertion, wheezing and chronic cough with expectoration. The physician suspecting COPD gets a spirometry assessment of the patient. The FEV1/FVC is 0.6 and the FEV1 was 66% of the predicted. What is the Global initiative for lung disease severity class of this patient?
questions.solution:
Global initiative for lung disease (GOLD) severity classification of this patient is Moderate severity.

The severity of COPD is assessed by Global Initiative for Lung Disease (GOLD) classification:

GOLD Stage Severity Spirometry
I Mild FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥80% predicted
II Moderate FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥50% but <80% predicted
III Severe FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥30% but <50% predicted
IV Very severe FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 <30% predicted

questions.text:
A 4-year-old girl is brought to PHC with complaints of cough, sore throat, fever and sandpaper rash over her trunk and extremities. Treatment of her condition will prevent which of the following complications?

PHC - Primary Healthcare Centre
questions.solution:
This patient with symptoms suggestieve of an upper respiratory tract infection ie cough, sore throat and fever along with sandpaper rash are suggestive of scarlet fever which is caused by beta-hemolytic streptococci. Acute rheumatic fever is one of the main indications for antibiotic treatment of streptococcal pharyngitis.

Post-infection sequelae of scarlet fever include rheumatic fever, glomerulonephritis, reactive arthritis, PANDAS(pediatric autoimmune neuropsychiatric disorders associated with streptococcal infection).

Scarlet fever  is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes, which produces pyrogenic exotoxins. The clinical features of scarlet fever are fever, rhinitis, strawberry tongue, and an erythematous sandpaper rash, which later desquamates. The tongue is coated and papillae are swollen and remain prominent after desquamation, giving rise to the strawberry appearance.

The following image shows strawberry tongue, also called raspberry tongue as seen in Scarlet fever.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old boy was brought by his parents to screen for thalassemia since both his parents are carriers of the disease. High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) was performed, and the result is given below. What is the diagnosis?

X-axis: Time (in min)

Y-axis: Analyte concentration (in %)
questions.solution:
The HPLC results show increased HbA2 and normal HbF values, pointing to a diagnosis of thalassemia trait.

β-thalassemia occurs due to mutations causing an impaired synthesis of β-globin chains of hemoglobin (Hb), leading to anemia, hypoxia, and hemolysis. The mutations can be of two types:

  1. Absent β chain synthesis (β0)
  2. Reduced β chain synthesis (β+)

Clinical syndromes of β-thalassemia depending on the genetic defect:

Major: 

  • Severe microcytic hypochromic anemia with target cells, basophilic stippling, and fragmented red cells (typical Hb: 3 to 6 g/dL), requiring regular blood transfusions
  • Crewcut appearance of facial bones and skull (due to cortical bone erosion by expanding marrow and new bone formation)
  • Speen, liver, and lymph node enlargement (due to extramedullary hematopoiesis)

Minor: 

  • More common
  • Usually asymptomatic
  • Mild microcytic hypochromic anemia with target cells and basophilic stippling (important to rule out iron deficiency anemia by serum iron studies)
  • Mild erythroid hyperplasia in bone marrow
  Major Minor (also called trait)
Genotype

β0/β0, β0/β+, β+/β+ (2 β-thalassemia alleles)

β/β0 or β/β+ (1 β-thalassemia allele and 1 normal allele)
Hb
electro-phoresis

HbF: Major Hb, markedly elevated

HbA2: Usually normal to low

HbA: Absent or present in small amounts

HbA2: Increased (4-8%) with an elevated ratio of δ-chain to β-chain synthesis

HbF: Normal or slightly increased

A third clinical syndrome of moderate severity is called β-thalassemia intermedia. The genotype in this type includes milder variants of β+/β+ or β0/β+ and does not require regular transfusions.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man has a history of diarrhea, stools sticking to the toilet pane, and weight loss for the past 2 years. The patient now presents with skin lesions as shown in the image. Which of the following is the best initial test to order for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of malabsorption with an image showing multiple, erythematous macules and papules over the abdomen (dermatitis herpetiformis) is suggestive of celiac disease. The best initial test to order in a patient with suspected celiac disease is anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies (tTG).

Celiac disease is a disorder characterized by an immunological response to gluten causing damage to the proximal intestinal mucosa, and malabsorption of nutrients. The typical symptoms include weight loss, anorexia, chronic diarrhea, abdominal distension, and growth retardation. The celiac disease–specific antibodies are anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies, endomysial antibodies (EMA), and antibodies against deamidated forms of gliadin peptides. HLA-DQ2 or DQ8 are present in most patients with celiac disease.

Complications of the disease include deficiencies of iron (most common), thiamine, vitamin B12, calcium, and vitamin D. Apart from this patients can also present with osteoporosis which can be reversed by a gluten-free diet, short stature, arthritis, and arthralgia. Extraintestinal manifestations include cardiomyopathy, erythema nodosum, dermatitis herpetiformis, peripheral neuropathies, irritability, and cerebellar ataxia. 

Endoscopy with small bowel biopsy is used as a confirmatory test to diagnose celiac disease and not as an initial test in suspected cases.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with history of schizophrenia comes to psychiatry OPD with symptoms of immobility, mutism, waxy flexibility and posturing. Which of the following is the appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient’s history of schizophrenia, mutism, and posturing are suggestive of catatonia for which benzodiazepine is the treatment of choice.

It is a syndrome of marked psychomotor disturbance that occurs in severely ill patients with psychotic disorders and medical conditions (infectious, metabolic, neurologic, and rheumatologic).

Lorazepam challenge test (IV 1-2 mg) resulting in partial, temporary relief within 5-10 minutes confirms the diagnosis.

ECT is recommended in urgent clinical situations or when the patient responds poorly to benzodiazepines.

questions.text: The minimum percentage of body surface area to be involved in order to treat the patient with IV fluids in a full thickness burn is:
questions.solution:
IV fluids are administered only when 20% of body surface area is involved in full thickness burn.

Burn injuries of less than 20% are associated with minimal fluid shifts and can generally be resuscitated with oral hydration, except in cases of facial, hand and genital burns, as well as burns in children and the elderly.

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children. 

Formulas provide a starting target rate; Subsequently, the amount of fluid provided should be adjusted based on urine output.

Category of burn Age Amount of Ringer’s Lactate given for 24 hours (ml) Target urine output (ml/kg/hour)
2nd/3rd-degree burns Adults  2 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 0.5
<14 years 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1
< 1 year or <30kgs 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA + 5% dextrose on a maintenance rate 1
4th-degree burns / Electrical burns All ages 4 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1-1.5 (until urine clears)

Dextrose maintenance:

  • 100 ml/ kg in 24 hours for 10 kg
  • 50 ml/kg for next 10 kg
  • 20 ml/kg for every kg after 20 kg

Evan’s formula is used for normal saline.

For the first 24 hours:

  • Amount of NS administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • Amount of colloid administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • 5% Dextrose administered= 2000 ml

After 24 hours, the amount of NS and colloid administered is half. 2000 ml of dextrose is maintained.

Muir and Barclay’s formula for colloids:

  • 1 portion of colloid = (weight in kgs x % TBSA)/2
  • 6 portions of colloid are administered over 36 hours

questions.text: A 5 year old boy was suffering from low grade fever, inspiratory stridor and barking cough for past 5 days. His chest X-ray is given below. What is the cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Barking cough is a feature of laryngotracheobronchitis, which is caused by the parainfluenza virus. The X-ray finding is the 'Steeple sign' due to subglottic narrowing.

The age of presentation of laryngotracheobronchitis ranges from 6 months-6 years. The clinical features include barking cough, inspiratory stridor, hoarseness, low-grade fever.

Management:

  • Racemic epinephrine nebulization leads to the rapid improvement of upper airway obstruction. Epinephrine constricts pre-capillary arterioles in the upper airway mucosa and decreases capillary hydrostatic pressure, leading to fluid resorption and improvement in airway edema.
  • Dexamethasone-by the least invasive route (Oral>IV>IM ). It is indicated in all the grades of croup.
  • Oxygen should be administered to children who are hypoxemic (SpO2 <92 %)

Antibiotics are not indicated in laryngotracheobronchitis.

questions.text:
A 7 year old boy was brought to hospital with complaints of day dreaming and a decline in school performance. His EEG was done which showed generalized 3 Hz spike wave activity occurring synchronously over both hemispheres as seen below:
Horizontal calibration : 1 sec
True statement is ___________

choices.text: Associated with head drop during seizure

questions.solution:
The 3 Hz spike and wave pattern given in the image above is characteristic of typical absence seizures. 

Drug of choice for simple childhood absence seizures is ethosuximide.

Absence seizures Atypical absence seizure
  • No change in body tone
  • Change in the tone of head and body
  • Precipitated by hyperventilation
  • Precipitated by drowsiness
  • 3Hz spike and wave pattern on EEG
  • 1-2 Hz spike and slow-wave pattern of EEG
  • Usually not associated with other syndromes
  • Associated with Lennox -Gestaut syndrome  

Lennox-Gastaut syndrome: (Option D)

  • Typically starts between the age of 2 and 10 years.
  • Consists of a triad of
    • Developmental delay
    • Multiple seizure types (includes atypical absences, myoclonic, astatic, and tonic seizures)
    • EEG findings 1-2 Hz spike and slow waves, polyspike bursts in sleep, and a slow background in wakefulness
  • Patients will have long-term cognitive impairment and intractable seizures despite multiple therapies.

questions.text: Image depicting inferior surface of brain is given below, herniation of colored area affects which of the following cranial nerves?
questions.solution:
Uncus along with Parahippocampal gyrus is depicted in the above image.

Transtentorial herniation of uncus can cause compression of 3rd cranial nerve, upper brainstem and cerebral peduncles.

It results from downward displacement of supratentorial structures into the infratentorial compartment.

It is caused by supratentorial mass lesions, diffuse brain swelling.

questions.text: Silverman anderson score is used to assess which of the following parameters?

choices.text: To assess disease severity in NICU

questions.solution:
Silverman Anderson score is used to assess severity of respiratory distress in neonates. Score >6 indicates impending respiratory failure.

questions.text: A patient complaints of vertigo, double vision and headache. He has fallen multiple times in the past few years and is unable to operate motor vehicles. Ophthalmologic examination is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The symptoms and the examination findings point towards a diagnosis of intranuclear ophthalmoplegia.

The site of lesion in a case of internuclear ophthalmoplegia is medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF).

The command for left gaze originates from right cerebral cortex and runs to the left paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF). An output from the left PPRF runs to the left VI nerve nucleus supplying the left lateral rectus, causing abduction. An output from the left PPRF also goes to the right III nerve nucleus via the right MLF causing right eye adduction.

Therefore, a lesion in the right MLF leads to failure of the right eye adduction. The left eye, however, abducts normally. This is called internuclear ophthalmoplegia.

questions.text: Contraindications to varenicline include all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Varenicline is one of the commonly used drug for smoking cessation. It is a partial agonist of subunit of nicotinic acetylcholine receptor that controls nicotine dependence. Varenicline is associated with neuropsychiatric side effects.

It should be avoided in patients with current unstable psychiatric status or recent suicidal ideation.

Bupropion is an alternative agent to varenicline but is contraindicated in patients with seizures.

questions.text: A 49-year-old man presents with flu-like symptoms and a palmoplantar rash as seen below. He has no history of chancre. On examination, he has epitrochlear lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the likely cause of this presentation?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of secondary syphilis. The absence of chancre is suggestive of a rare form of syphilis called syphilis d'emblee, where syphilis is transmitted through blood transfusion.

In this condition, there are no primary lesions and the disease directly presents in the secondary stage. It is treated as per usual guidelines with benzathine penicillin G 2.4 mega units IM single dose or 2 doses on days 1 and 8.

Option A: Sexual contact would present initially with a chancre at the primary site of contact.

Option C and D: Endemic treponemal infections such as yaws can be transmitted by direct skin-to-skin contact. It causes skin and bone deformities. Painless, indurated ulcers are seen, which are common over the legs and ankles.

questions.text: The lab technician notices a urine sample from a 40 year old male that was normal on collection turning to the colour shown in the image after a few hours. It further darkened over the next few hours. Which of the following statements will not hold true for the patient?

choices.text: Patient should have pain and stiffness of his back
Patient will have history of staining of his clothes by his sweat
Intervertebral space expansion is noted on X-rays
Treatment is initiated with Vitamin C for the patient

questions.solution:
Intervertebral space narrowing, not expansion, is seen in case of Alkaptonuria.

The image shows a urine sample that turned brown on standing and had further darkened later. This is suggestive of Alkaptonuria (Homogentisic aciduria).

The urine contains homogentisic acid which on oxidation and polymerization turns black.

The disease is caused due to deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase, an autosomal recessive disorder.


Other clinical features:-

  • Bluish-black pigmentation of ear cartilage and/or sclera due to deposits of accumulated Homogentisic acid.
  • Pain and stiffness of spine & larger joints - after 3rd decade
  • Staining of clothes by the homogentisic acid in the sweat

The X-Ray shows characteristic intervertebral space narrowing and calcification.
Treatment is with Vit. C 1g/Day. The antioxidant property of Vit. C helps to prevent the conversion to the polymeric material that is deposited in joints.

questions.text: The given image shows what grade of placenta previa?
questions.solution:
The given image shows grade III placenta previa. 

Placenta previa refers to the placenta implanted (partially/completely) over the lower uterine segment (over or adjacent to the internal os). Grades of placenta previa are:

  •  Type—I (Low-lying): The major part of the placenta is attached to the upper segment and only the
    lower margin encroaches onto the lower segment but not up to the os.
  • Type—II (Marginal): The placenta reaches the margin of the internal os but does not cover it.
  • Type—III (Incomplete or partial central): The placenta covers the internal os partially (covers the
    internal os when closed but does not entirely do so when fully dilated).
  • Type—IV (Central or total): The placenta completely covers the internal os even after it is fully dilated.

They typically present with sudden onset, painless vaginal bleeding. On vulval inspection, bright red blood is seen oozing from the cervical opening. Transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) is used to confirm the diagnosis and position of the placenta.

Management is dependent on the presentation of the patient. If there is a need for fetal maturity, expectant management (advocated by McAfee and Johnson) is carried out without increasing undue maternal stress. Definitive management by an elective cesarean section.

questions.text: Identify the true statement about the staging of cancer cervix.

choices.text: Clinical examination is the first step in staging
Tumor markers are important for diagnosis of metastasis
CT scan is the best method to assess principal tumors
MRI is the best method to assess nodal metastasis

questions.solution:
Clinical examination is the first step in staging carcinoma cervix.

Clinical examination was the principal method in staging until the 2018 FIGO guidelines which recommended the use of imaging and histological investigations when available. USG, CT, MRI, and PET-CT can be used to assess the extent of the tumor, nodal status, and local or systemic spread.

MRI is the best method to assess the principal tumor while PET-CT is the best method to assess nodal metastasis.

FIGO no longer mandates biochemical investigations, such as tumor markers, for diagnosis of metastasis.

Related Pearl: Staging of Carcinoma Cervix

Stage I - limited to the cervix

  • A: Microscopic lesion
    • A1 - stromal invasion <3mm depth
    • A2 - a stromal invasion of ≥3 and <5mm depth
  • B: Macroscopic lesion
    • B1 - stromal invasion ≥5mm depth & tumor size <2cm 
    • B2 - tumor size ≥2cm to <4cm 
    • B3 - tumor size ≥4cm 

Stage II - involves upper 2/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to the upper two-thirds of the vagina without parametrial involvement
    • A1 - tumor size <4cm 
    • A2 - tumor size ≥4cm 
  • B: Extends to parametrium but not upto the pelvic wall.

Stage III - spreads to lower 1/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to lower 1/3 of the vagina
  • B: Extends to the pelvic wall (hydronephrosis/non-functioning kidney)
  • C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or para-aortic lymph nodes, irrespective of the tumor size and extent
    • C1: pelvic lymph node involved
    • C2: para-aortic lymph node involved

Stage IV - metastasis

  • A: Bladder/bowel involvement (adjacent pelvic organs)
  • B: Distant metastasis

Note: The involvement of vascular/lymphatic spaces does not change the staging. The lateral extent of the lesion is no longer considered.

Stage IIIB is the most common stage of presentation.

questions.text: Post-translational modification of glutamate requires which of the following vitamin?
questions.solution: Vitamin K dependent carboxylase is involved in conversion of glutamic acid into gamma carboxyglutamic acid residues.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presented with pain and swelling of left middle finger. Investigations revealed normal serum calcium, phosphorus, alkaline phosphatase and PTH levels. The X-ray image is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Plain X-ray shows a solitary lytic lesion in the epiphysis of third proxmal phallanx of left hand suggestive of giant cell tumor.

The X-ray depicts Giant cell tumor (GCT) which can be identified by the following points:

  • Epiphyseal tumor (next to the joint surface) and extending to the metaphyseal region.
  • Characteristic "soap bubble appearance" with free septations.
  • Eccentrically located lytic lesion in the epiphyses of long bones which frequently breaks through the cortex.

Other options:

Option b: Brown tumor is a lytic lesion in the bone that occurs secondary to hyperparathyroidsim and resembles giant cell tumor. Normal levels of serum calcium, phosphorus, alkaline phosphatase, and parathyroid hormone levels rule out hyperparathyroidism. The image below shows brown tumor of left hand.

Option c: Chondroblastoma usually appears as a well-circumscribed, lytic lesion in the center of the epiphysis of a long bone as shown below. The lesion is usually surrounded by a rim of reactive bone.

Option d: Enchondromas are benign lesions of hyaline cartilage that ocur in the medullary canal of the bones. They are usually asymptomatic. It can occur in any bone in the body, however, the phalanges of the hand are commonly involved. Calcified lesions are usually seen on X-ray as shown in the image below.

questions.text: The following statements are True/False regarding APACHE II Score
questions.solution:
• APACHE II stands for Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation II Score
  • The APACHE II system is the most commonly used severity-of-illness scoring system in North America.
  • The APACHE II score is the sum of the
    1. Acute physiology score (Vital signs including Heart rate, Oxygenation, Laboratory values)
    2. Glasgow coma score
    3. Age
    4. Chronic health points.

questions.text: What is the immunophenotype of tumor cells in multiple myeloma?
questions.solution:
The immunophenotype of tumor cells in multiple myeloma is CD38 and CD138.

Multiple myeloma is derived from plasma cells in which B cell markers (CD19, CD20) are lost.

Immunophenotype of tumor cells in lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma / Waldenstrom's macroglobulinemia is CD19, CD20, surface IgM+, CD38. A lymphoplasmacytic cell retains B cell markers and carries plasma cell markers.

questions.text:
Choose the appropriate option regarding Fonseca’s disease:
  1. This is the most common form of Chromomycosis.
  2. Sclerotic bodies can be seen on histological examination.
  3. It is also called as Verrucous dermatitis.
  4. Surgical excision with wide margins is the therapy of choice for large lesions.
questions.solution:
Chromoblastomycosis is also called as Fonseca’s disease.

  • Chromoblastomycosis is a subcutaneous mycotic infection that is usually caused by traumatic inoculation of fungal agents, which reside in soil and vegetation.
  • All are dematiaceous fungi, having melanized cell walls: Phialophora verrucosa, Fonsecaea pedrosoi, Fonsecaea compacta, Rhinocladiella aquaspersa and Cladophialophora carrionii.
  • This is the most common form of Chromomycisis.
  • The primary lesion becomes verrucous and wart-like with extension along the draining lymphatics. Cauliflower-like nodules with crusting abscesses eventually cover the area.
  • Diagnosis can be established by demonstrating the Sclerotic bodies in KOH mounts or tissue sections.
  • Surgical excision with wide margins is the therapy of choice for small lesions. Chemotherapy with flucytosine or itraconazole may be efficacious for larger lesions.

questions.text: While conducting a health camp, you host an awareness campaign on healthy dietary practices. Which of the following substances would you say has the highest respiratory quotient immediately after consumption?
questions.solution:
The food item with the highest respiratory quotient (RQ) immediately after consumption is a mixed diet. 

This is because, immediately after a mixed meal (containing carbohydrates, protein, and fat), carbohydrates is the most commonly metabolized component, so the RQ reaches 1. But, a few hours after, the body would have used up the readily available carbohydrates, and the RQ reaches 0.70, due to fat metabolism.

The respiratory quotient is the ratio of carbon dioxide produced/oxygen consumed. The respiratory quotient for various substances:

Substance RQ
Carbohydrate 1.00 
Protein (option D) 0.81 
Fat (option B) 0.71  
Alcohol (option C) 0.66 

In diabetes, the rate of utilization of carbohydrates reduces in relation to fats, hence RQ falls (approximately 0.7). The RQ is lowest when ketosis is very active.

Note: For all metabolic fuels, the energy produced is the same (20 kJ/L of oxygen).

questions.text:
In the TCA cycle, which of the following intermediates inhibits the rate-limiting enzyme of glycolysis and activates the rate-limiting enzyme of fatty acid synthesis?

TCA- Tricarboxylic acid cycle
questions.solution:
Citrate acts as a key regulatory molecule in glycolysis and fatty acid synthesis.

Citrate inhibits phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1), the rate-limiting enzyme of glycolysis. Phosphofructokinase-1 catalyses the phosphorylation of fructose-6-phosphate into fructose-1,6-phosphate.

Inhibitors of PFK-1: ATP, Citrate
Allosteric activators of PFK-1: AMP, ADP, and fructose 2,6-bisphosphate (Most potent activator)
Hormonal regulation:

  • Inducer—Insulin
  • Repressor—Glucagon


Citrate also activates acetyl-CoA carboxylase, the rate-limiting enzyme of fatty acid synthesis. Acetyl-CoA carboxylase catalyses the carboxylation of acetyl-CoA to form malonyl-CoA.

Inhibitors of acetyl-CoA carboxylase: long-chain acyl CoA, glucagon, epinephrine, and phosphorylation 
Activators of acetyl-CoA carboxylase: Citrate, insulin, and dephosphorylation

questions.text: The correct order of stage of death, as proposed by Kubler Ross is ______
questions.solution:
Denial - Anger - Bargaining - Depression - Acceptance is the correct order of stage of death, as proposed by Kubler Ross. 

Elisabeth Kubler-Ross, a psychiatrist, and thanatologist made an organization of reactions to impending death.

The following five stages proposed by Kubler-Ross are widely encountered:

  • Shock and Denial
    • On being told that they are dying, persons initially react with shock.
    • They may refuse to believe the diagnosis; they may deny that anything is wrong.
  • Anger 
    • Persons become frustrated, irritable, and angry at being ill.
    • They commonly ask, "Why me?"
  • Bargaining 
    • Patients may attempt to negotiate with physicians, friends, or even God; in return for a cure, they promise to fulfill one or many pledges, such as giving to charity.
  • Depression 
    • In the fourth stage, patients show clinical signs of depression – withdrawal, psychomotor retardation, sleep disturbances, hopelessness, and, possibly, suicidal ideation.
  • Acceptance 
    • In the stage of acceptance, patients realize that death is inevitable, and they accept the universality of the experience.
    • Their feelings can range from a neutral to a euphoric mood.

questions.text: Haddon matrix is related to:
questions.solution:
The Haddon Matrix is paradigm used in the research on injury prevention and intervention , developed by William Haddon.

Matrix looks at factors related to personal attributes, vector or agent attributes and environmental attributes; before, during and after an injury or death

questions.text: Xeroderma pigmentosum is an inherited skin condition that can cause dry skin, light sensitivity, and skin cancer. Which of the following explains the molecular basis of the disease?
questions.solution:
Defects in the nucleotide excision repair (NER) pathway is the molecular basis of xeroderma pigmentosum (XP).

XP is a rare inherited disorder characterized by extreme sensitivity to ultraviolet (UV) light from the sun, leading to sunburn, and skin aging. It is a premalignant condition and patients are at an increased risk of developing skin cancer. Exposure to UV rays leads to the formation of DNA pyrimidine dimers. 

NER is a DNA repair mechanism that removes DNA lesions, such as UV-induced pyrimidine dimers. Repair predominantly occurs in the G1 phase of the cell cycle.

Other options: 

Option A: Mismatch repair is a separate DNA repair pathway responsible for correcting base-pairing errors during DNA replication. Mutations in mismatch repair genes are associated with Lynch syndrome.

Options B and D: Base excision repair is another DNA repair pathway that corrects small DNA lesions, such as single-base modifications (depurination). Defects in base excision repair are not responsible for xeroderma pigmentosum.

Related Pearl: Human Diseases of DNA Damage Repair

questions.text: The markers of the tumors with the given histopathological sections are, respectively:
questions.solution:
Image A: Schiller-Duval body characteristic of endodermal sinus tumor. AFP is the tumor marker of these tumors.

Endodermal sinus tumor/Yolk sac tumor is the second most common malignant ovarian tumor.

Schiller -Duval bodies are pathognomonic on histopathology. This structure consists of a central capillary surrounded by tumor cells, present within a cystic space that may be lined by flat to cuboidal tumor cells.

The below image shows Schiller- Duval bodies.


Image B: Tumor cells are arranged in sheets punctuated by small follicle-like structures(Call-Exner bodies) characteristic of Granulosa cell tumor. Inhibin is a marker for these tumors.

Granulosa cell tumors are ovarian sex-cord stromal tumors made up of cells closely resembling the granulosa cells of the ovarian follicle. The majority of the time it is seen in post-menopausal women.

These tumors are usually unilateral. In adult women, they may be associated with proliferative breast disease, endometrial hyperplasia, and endometrial carcinoma. The presence of this tumor in prepubertal girls may lead to precocious puberty. The serum and tissue inhibin levels are elevated.

The cut section is soft and has a yellowish reticular or trabecular appearance with interstitial hemorrhage. On microscopy, Call-exner bodies are seen which are small, distinctive, glandlike structures filled with an acidophilic material that recall immature follicles. 

The image below shows Call-exner bodies.


Image C: Epithelial ovarian tumors arise from the mesoepithelial cells present on the ovarian and fallopian tubal surfaces. CA-125 is a marker for these tumors.

80% of all ovarian cancers are epithelial cancers. Malignant epithelial cell tumors of the ovary secrete CA-125. It is a glycoprotein and surface cell antigen which is secreted by malignant epithelial tumors of the ovary. A level of more than 35 U/mL suggests a malignant and residual tumor and indicates the need for chemotherapy.

CA-125 is also raised in abdominal tuberculosis and endometriosis. It may not be helpful in the initial diagnosis, once the diagnosis is established, a raised level of CA-125 indicates either persistence or recurrence of the disease in the follow-up.

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Pathognomonic finding

Epithelial ovarian tumors

  • D: Dysgerminoma
  • P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)
  • L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

questions.text: All are true about FDG -PET except

choices.text: False negative results are seen in tumors with slow growth and low metabolism
The blood glucose level has no role in standardized uptake of FDG in lung and brain
Tumors <7mm in diameter may not be detected by FDG-PET
A standardized uptake value of >2.5 raises the possibility of malignant disease

questions.solution:
An elevated serum glucose level decreases intracellular FDG uptake in the brain because the FDG and glucose compete for the same cell surface receptor. While lung was least affected by the blood glucose level.

Quantification of the amount of radioactivity is obtained by calculating the standardized uptake value.

questions.text: The type of cartilage in synchondroses type of joint
questions.solution:
Hyaline cartilage is seen in synchondroses type of joint.

Synchondroses are cartilaginous unions between bone composed entirely of hyaline cartilage.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is biopsied for the diagnosis of pure neuritic leprosy?
questions.solution:
Superficial sensory branch of the radial nerve is most commonly used for nerve biopsy in neuritic leprosy.

Although any nerve involved would show the pathology, it is prudent to biopsy a branch of a sensory nerve, rather than a mixed nerve or major nerve trunk. So, the ulnar nerve will not be the best answer despite it being the most common peripheral nerve involved in neuritic leprosy.

The common nerves and sites where nerve biopsy is performed in leprosy are as follows:

  • Superficial sensory radial nerve branch at the wrist
  • Ulnar cutaneous nerve near the ulnar border of the base of the hand
  • Sural nerve near the ankle

Note: Nerve biopsy is the gold standard for confirmation of pure neuritic leprosy.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl was brought to the psychiatric emergency department after she slashed her wrist in an attempt to commit suicide. Her father reveals that there were multiple such attempts in the past. She has a history of marked fluctuations of mood and unstable relationships in the past. Which of the following non-pharmacological therapy is advised for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of borderline personality disorder. The psychotherapy advised for this patient is dialectical behavioral therapy.

Psychotherapy is the treatment of choice for borderline personality disorder. Dialectical behavior therapy (DBT), transference-focused psychotherapy (TFP), and mentalization-based therapy (MBT) are the various psychotherapies used in the treatment of this condition. There is no consensus as to which particular therapy (viz. DBT, TFP, or MBT) is superior to the others.

A borderline personality disorder is characterized by extraordinarily unstable affect, mood, behavior, object relations, and self-image. According to DSM-5, a diagnosis of borderline personality disorder can be made if at least 5 out of the following are shown by the patient:

  • Panicky efforts to avoid real or imagined abandonment
  • Unstable interpersonal relationships
  • Marked and persistently unstable self-image or sense of self
  • Impulsivity in at least two areas of potentially self-damaging like sex, substance abuse, reckless driving, binge eating, etc.
  • Repeated suicidal behavior, gestures, threats, or self-mutilating behavior
  • Instability in affect due to a marked reactivity of mood
  • Prolonged feeling of emptiness
  • Inappropriate, intense anger or difficulty in controlling anger
  • Transient stress-related paranoid ideation

Psychotherapy is the treatment of choice for borderline personality disorder. 

Antipsychotics help to control anger, hostility, and brief psychotic episodes. Antidepressants are used to improve depressive mood which is common in patients with borderline personality disorder.

Monoamine oxidase inhibitors help in the modulation of impulsive behavior and benzodiazepine-like alprazolam helps in improving anxiety and depression. Anticonvulsants like carbamazepine help in improving the global functioning of patients with borderline personality disorder. 

Other options:

Interpersonal psychotherapy is used in the treatment of depression. It focuses on grief over loss, interpersonal disputes, interpersonal skill deficits, and role transitions.

Exposure and response prevention is used in the treatment of OCD.

Related Pearl: Personality Disorders

questions.text:
Choose the most appropriate option pertaining to Stevens's power law
  1. It is given by : Interpreted signal strength = K X (Stimulus - k)y
  2. It is given by : Interpreted signal strength = Log (Stimulus) + Constant
  3. It is often considered to supersede the Weber–Fechner law, because the power law describes a wider range of sensory comparisons.
  4. Weber–Fechner law supersedes Stevens's power law, because it detects the ratio of stimulus strength
questions.solution:
Stevens's power law gives an empirical relationship in psychophysics between an increased intensity or strength in a physical stimulus and the perceived magnitude increase in the sensation created by the stimulus.

  • It is often considered to supersede the Weber–Fechner law, based on a logarithmic relationship between stimulus and sensation, because the power law describes a wider range of sensory comparisons.
  • It is given by: Interpreted signal strength = K X (Stimulus - k)y

questions.text: The following upper GI series shows:
questions.solution:
The upper GI series shows Zenker's diverticulum.

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure

questions.text: What type of antagonism is shown by drugs A and B in the following dose-response curve?
questions.solution:
The parallel rightward shift of the agonist dose-response curve (DRC) is seen with competitive antagonism.

Increasing the dose of the agonist can result in the same maximal response.

In non-competitive antagonism, there will be flattening of the agonist DRC.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding the given statements:

Assertion: Accumulation of sulfur-containing amino acid in the bloodstream in the deficiency of cystathionine-β-synthase, increases cardiovascular risk.

Reason: In the above case, decreased dietary intake of methionine, decreases the formation of homocysteine.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true, the reason is the correct explanation of assertion
Both assertion and reason are true but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is true but the reason is false
Assertion is false but the reason is true

questions.solution:
• Defect in the metabolism of sulfur-containing amino acids (homocysteine) due to the deficiency of cystathionine-β-synthase leads to its accumulation.
  • Homocysteine is highly cytotoxic and elevated levels within the bloodstream are believed to damage the endothelial lining of arterial vessels, leading to intravascular coagulation.

Related Pearl: Homocystinuria

The concept for treatment:

  • Since homocysteine is produced from methionine, decreased dietary intake of methionine decreases the formation of homocysteine.
  • As the end product of this cycle is cysteine, increased dietary intake of cysteine will decrease the conversion of methionine to homocysteine through negative feedback.

questions.text: A 72 year old patient who is a known case of COPD comes to the emergency with complaints of shortness of breath, cough, headaches, weight loss, increased sputum production and chest pain for the past 1 week. The patient had similar such episodes over the past 5 years. The patient is admitted and treated accordingly. His PaO2 shows 52% in room air.  At the time of discharge the patient requests for treatment which would prolong his survival chances from the disease. Which of the following is the best treatment as per the patient's request?
questions.solution:
The treatment that would best prolong his survival chances is Home oxygen therapy.

This patient, is a known case of COPD presents with the symptoms of an acute exacerbation of COPD.

Home oxygen therapy and smoking cessations are the only measures known to decrease mortality in COPD.

The indications for home oxygen therapy are:

  • Resting O2 saturation (SaO2) ≤88%
  • Resting O2 saturation <90% with signs of pulmonary hypertension or right heart failure
  • Partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) ≤55%
  • Hematocrit >55%
  • Cor pulmonale

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient came with complaints of nasal congestion, stuffiness, discharge, and anosmia. CT scan of paranasal sinuses shows mucosal thickening with centrally hyperdense areas. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Allergic fungal sinusitis is the most probable diagnosis based on the above findings.

It is an allergic reaction to the causative fungus. There is no invasion of the sinus mucosa with fungus. It presents with sinonasal polyposis and mucin which consists of eosinophils, Charcot Leyden crystal, and fungal hyphae. 

CT scan shows mucosal thickening with centrally hyperdense areas. There is an expansion of the sinus or bone erosion due to pressure but no fungal invasion.

Treatment: Endoscopic surgical drainage and ventilation along with systemic steroids.

Other options:

Option B: Ethmoidal polyps are multiple and bilateral and arise from the lateral wall of the nose. Patients are mostly adults and present with bilateral nasal obstruction, anosmia/ hyposmia, sneezing, rhinorrhea, and a polypoidal mass from the nostril.

Option C: Antrochoanal polyp (Killian's polyp) arises from the mucosa of the maxillary antrum. They are usually unilateral and are seen in children and young adults. They present with unilateral nasal obstruction. X-rays of the paranasal sinuses show opacity of the maxillary sinus,

Option D: Nasoethmoidal carcinoma presents with nasal obstruction, blood-stained nasal discharge, diplopia, lateral displacement of the eyeball, broadening of nasal root, and retro-orbital pain.

questions.text: Which of the following skin findings in a newborn is most likely associated with an underlying pathology?
questions.solution:
Nevus flammeus also known as Port wine stain is seen in babies with Sturge Weber syndrome.

It is located over the distribution of V1 branch of the trigeminal nerve.

Pustular melanosis is a benign rash characterized by small, dry vesicles over a dark macular base.

Milia small cysts formed around the pilosebaceous follicles usually seen over nose, cheek, forehead.

Erythema toxicum neonatorum is a benign rash usually in first 72 hours of life, it is characterized by erythematous maculopapular pustules on trunk and extremities.

The following image shows Port-wine stain:

questions.text: The following image shows:
questions.solution:
The following image shows the Swirl sign. It is an area of low attenuation within an extraaxial hyperattenuating fluid collection.

The term "swirl sign" describes the appearance on a non-contrast CT scan when fresh blood leaks into a hematoma, such as in intracerebral, extradural, or subdural hematomas. This indicates the presence of unclotted blood, which appears lighter than the surrounding clotted blood.
 

Other options:

  • Mount Fuji sign - This sign is present in case of pneumocephalus. Gas is present between the tips of the frontal lobes with heaped up appearance giving the silhouette-like appearance.
  • Ice cream cone sign-it represents the normal appearance of malleus and incus on an HRCT.
  • Accordion sign/concertina sign is a non-specific sign related to a thickened edematous large bowel wall usually seen in CT abdomen of patients with infectious colitis.

questions.text: The image shows recent X Ray images set of a person. Based on the age conclusion you draw from it, which of the following medicolegal significance has been wrongly concluded?

choices.text: This person would not be considered major if he was under court guardianship
If the person were a boy he wouldn’t be old enough to enter into a  marriage
If the person were a female and had been imported into India recently, illicit intercourse would be punishable by Sec 366 B

questions.solution:
The approximate age of this person based on the  X-Ray is at least 21 years.

Bone/ joint Maximum age at fusion Interpretation of given X-ray
Elbow joint centres 16 years Fused, >16 years
Wrist joint centres 19 years Fused, > 19 years
Hip bone centres 22 years Fused, > 21 years

Since all the above centres are fused in this person, the age must be more than 21 years.

  1. Legal age for marriage for boys
  2. Illicit intercourse by a female imported into India is punishable under Sec 366 B IPC if the female is less than 21 years of age 
  3. A person under the guardianship of the Court would be considered a major after the age of 21 years.

Hence, all of the options are wrong regarding the medicolegal significance of 21 years. 

For estimation of age between 6 to 12 years take X-rays of elbow and wrist joint - 

  • 6 years - Appearance of centre for the lower end of ulna and medial epicondyle of the humerus.
  • 9 years - Appearance of olecranon
  • 9 to 11 years - Appearance of trochlea of humerus
  • 10 to 11 years - Appearance of pisiform
  • 11 years - Appearance of lateral epicondyle of humerus 

For estimation of age between 13 to 16 years take X-rays of elbow joint and pelvis.

  • 13 years - Appearance of separate centers in triradiate cartilage of acetabulum.
  • 12 to 14 years - Appearance of lesser trochanter of femur.
  • 14 years - Appearance of iliac crest and fusion of medial epicondyle of humerus. 
  • 15 years - Fusion of triradiate cartilage of acetabulum.
  • 16years - Appearance of ischial tuberosity and fusion of lower end of humerus, olecranon to ulna and upper end of radius.

Age at which fusion of bones/joints- 

  • 16 years - Elbow joint
  • 16 to 17 years - ankle joint 
  • 17 to 18 years - Hip joint
  • 18 to 19 years - Knee, shoulder and wrist joints
  • 20 to 21 years - Fusion of ileac crest, ischial tuberosity and inner end of the clavicle.

questions.text: A smoker suspected to have polycythemia, undergoes a series of laboratory tests which reveal an elevated RBC mass, elevated serum Erythropoietin(EPO) levels and normal O2 saturation. What is the next best step in the investigation of this patient?
questions.solution:
The next ideal step would be to measure carboxyhemoglobin levels.

  • An elevated level would confirm the diagnosis of Smoker's polycythemia.
  • However if the carboxyhemoglobin levels are normal, then O2 Hemoglobin affinity is measured to either confirm O2 affinity hemoglobinopathy (increased affinity) or search for other tumors (normal affinity). 

Other options:

  • O2 Hemoglobin affinity would have been measured earlier if the patient in the given question was a non-smoker.
  • Jak-2 levels are measured only if EPO levels are low and Polycythemia Vera is suspected.
  • Evaluation for COPD, heart disease, or intracardiac shunt is necessary only if the O2 saturation is low.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding the given statements:

Assertion: Infusion of parathyroid hormone causes bone resorption by upregulation of osteoclastic activity.     

Reason: Parathyroid hormone (PTH) binds to receptors on immature osteoclasts, and stimulates them to form mature osteoclasts.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are correct and reason is the correct explanation of assertion
Both assertion and reason are correct and reason is not the correct explanation of assertion
Assertion is correct and the reason is wrong
Assertion is wrong and the reason is correct

questions.solution:
• The assertion is correct and statement two is wrong as PTH first binds to receptors on osteoblasts, causing them to form receptor activator for nuclear factor κ-B ligand (RANKL) and to release macrophage-colony stimulating factor (M-CSF).
  • RANKL binds to RANK and M-CSF binds to its receptors on preosteoclast cells, causing them to differentiate into mature osteoclasts.
  • Osteoblasts also produce osteoprotegerin (OPG), that inhibits bone resorption by preventing interaction of RANKL with its receptor.

questions.text: In the pressure–volume graph shown below, compliance of lung is represented by _________.
questions.solution:
In the given pressure–volume graph:

  • A – Compliance of chest
  • B – Compliance of lung
  • C – Compliance of lung and chest wall 

The equilibrium position is at functional residual capacity (FRC), where the expanding force on the chest wall is exactly equal to the collapsing force on the lungs. FRC is also known as relaxation volume and represents the amount of air remaining in the lungs at the end of normal expiration.

At the point where volume= FRC,

  • Intraalveolar pressure is equal to atmospheric pressure and considered as zero.
  • Intrapleural pressure is negative (-2.5 mmHg)
  • Transpulmonary pressure = Intraalveolar pressure – intrapleural pressure = 0 – (-2.5 mmHg) = +2.5 mmHg.  

For compliance of lung – Pressure considered is Transpulmonary pressure. So at FRC, Transpulmonary pressure is positive (+2.5 mmHg). Hence, B indicates compliance of lung.  

For compliance of chest wall – Pressure considered is intrapleural – atmospheric pressure. At FRC, this value is -2.5 mmHg. Hence, A represents compliance of the chest wall.  

When the volume is FRC, the combined lung and chest-wall curve intersects the X-axis at an airway pressure of zero. Hence, C represents the combined chest wall and lung compliance.

questions.text: True statement about Beta- HCG is:

choices.text: The doubling time of serum hCG concentration is 3 days
Beta HCG and LH acts through the same receptor
Chromosome 6 codes for alpha subunit, while chromosome 18 codes for beta subunit
The level of beta HCG begins to fall from 10th week of pregnancy

questions.solution:
Beta HCG and LH act through the same receptor.

  • The luteinizing hormone/choriogonadotropin receptor is a transmembrane receptor found in the ovary, testis, uterus and breasts. The receptor interacts with both luteinizing hormone (LH) and chorionic gonadotropins and represents a G protein-coupled receptor (GPCR). 
  • The doubling time of serum hCG concentration is 1.4 to 2.0 days.
  • Chromosome 6 codes for alpha subunit, while chromosome 19 codes for beta subunit.
  • The levels of Beta-HCG starts falling from 13-16 weeks onwards.

questions.text: Sagittal section of brain is given below. Labelled white matter fibers represent which of the following?
questions.solution:
The image represents Association fibres which connect cortical regions within the same cerebral hemisphere.

Main white matter tracts in CNS can be classified into three types:

Projection fibres: Project from higher to lower centres or vice versa in CNS.

  • Corona radiata
  • Internal capsule
  • Fimbria

Association fibers: Connect cortical regions within same cerebral hemispheres

  • Uncinate fasciculus
  • Cingulum
  • Superior longitudinal fasciculus
  • Inferior longitudinal fasciculus
  • Fornix
  • Arcuate fasciculus

Commisural fibres: Transverse fibres that interconnect similar regions in both hemispheres of CNS

  • Corpus callosum
  • Hippocampal commissure
  • Anterior and posterior commissure
  • Habenular commissure

Related Pearl: White matter tracts of the brain

Commissural fibers: connect corresponding regions of two hemispheres.

They include

  • Corpus callosum
  • Anterior and posterior commissure
  • Habenular commissure
  • Hippocampal commissure of fornix

Association fibers: connect various cortical regions within the same hemisphere.

They are classified as 

  • Short association fibers: lie immediately under the cortex and connect adjacent gyri. Eg- arcuate fasciculus
  • Long association fibers:
    • Uncinate fasciculus
    • Cingulum
    • Superior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Inferior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Fronto-occipital fasciculus
    • Fornix (except hippocampal commissure of fornix)

Projection fibers: fibers passing to and from the brainstem to the cerebral cortex. 

  • Internal capsule
  • Corona radiata

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to your OPD with history of sudden onset lesions in the back as shown in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a seborrheic keratoses.

Seborrheic keratoses are multiple eruptive lesions over the back, abdomen, and neck. This acute onset of an increase in size and number of seborrheic keratoses is a sign of internal malignancy called the sign of Leser-Trélat. 

When it is associated with pruritus or acanthosis nigricans, especially in younger patients, it warrants investigation for internal malignancy. About 1/3rd of associated tumours are in the gastrointestinal tract, and about half of these tumours are adenocarcinomas.

tracts

pancreatic islet cell adenoma

Involvement of EAS>50% is considered as Grade 3b laceration.

GRADES OF PERINEAL LACERATION:

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for scrub typhus during pregnancy and otherwise respectively?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for a case of scrub typhus during pregnancy is azithromycin. For other patients the drug of choice is doxycycline.

An alternative treatment option in pregnant women and patients allergic to doxycycline is chloramphenicol.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old HIV-positive patient who was diagnosed with MDR-TB was put on bedaquiline therapy. Which of the following is false about this drug?

MDR-TB :multidrug-resistant tuberculosis
questions.solution:
Bedaquiline does not reduce treatment duration in MDR-TB.

Bedaquiline/ Sirturo is a bactericidal drug that belongs to diarylquinolines. It acts by inhibiting the enzyme ATP synthase in the Mycobacterium. According to the National TB 

Elimination Program (NTEP), it is used as an add-on drug for pulmonary MDR-TB in adults >18 years.

Dosage of bedaquiline:

  • Week 0–2: 400 mg daily
  • Week 3–24: 200 mg thrice a week (with at least 48 hours between doses) 

Adverse effects of bedaquiline include cardiotoxicity (QT prolongation) and hepatotoxicity.

Muti-drug resistant (MDR) tuberculosis (TB) shows resistance to isoniazid and rifampicin. The treatment of MDR-TB is curated with drugs grouped into different classes by the World Health Organization (WHO):

  • Group A: Levofloxacin, bedaquiline, linezolid
  • Group B: Clofazimine, cycloserine
  • Group C: Ethambutol, pyrazinamide, delamanid (newer add-on drug), ethionamide, p-aminosalicylic acid

In patients treated previously or with additional drug resistance, a longer MDR-TB regimen of 18-20 months is recommended. Drugs belonging to group A are preferred along with one drug from group B whenever possible. In patients not treated before and without the extensive disease, a shorter regimen of 6 months intensive phase with bedaquiline and other drugs is used. The other drugs are continued for 5 months-continuation phase. In pregnant women with MDR-TB, drugs such as bedaquiline and delamanid should be avoided. 

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

The cases are classified as:

  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

questions.text: Phenylbutyrate is used in urea cycle disorder because
questions.solution:
Phenyl butyrate (pro drug) is an orphan drug, which is approved for treatment of hyperammonemia in patients with urea cycle disorders.

It undergoes conversion to phenyl acetate in liver and kidney.

Phenyl acetate then conjugates with glutamine to form phenylacetylglutamine, which can be readily excreted in urine thereby removing ammonia from the body. One mole of phenyl acetate removes two moles of ammonia as glutamine from the body.

questions.text: A young patient came with complaints of acute abdominal pain on and off and tingling sensation of limbs and at times weakness of limbs. She had a history of eating paint from the wall of newly built house. Which of the following enzyme defect will be the cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of lead poisoning in children is seen due to lead paint and according to the history, it is evident that the case is of lead poisoning and the enzyme defect seen is ALA dehydratase.

Lead is toxic because it can substitute for calcium in many fundamental cellular processes. Lead can cross red blood cell membranes as well as the blood–brain barrier and enter the neuroglia cells which support brain function.

Heme biosynthesis is initiated by the condensation of succinyl–CoA and glycine in a reaction catalyzed by mitochondrial ALA Synthase.

Condensation of two molecules of ALA, catalyzed by cytosolic ALA dehydratase forms porphobilinogen which is essential in heme synthesis.

Fatal dose: 20g of lead acetate

Fatal period: 1 to 2 days.

Symptoms:

Abdominal pain, headache, anemia, irritability and, in severe cases, seizures, coma and death.

Diagnosis

X-rays will expose dense lines in the long bones of children and red cells undergo a change known as basophilic stippling, where blue-staining remnants of destroyed DNA are seen lining the margins of the red cells.

The main tool for diagnosis is measurement of the blood lead level.

Treatment depends on the blood level and is designed to remove the lead from the body by chelation therapy.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding the given statements:

Assertion: CD49 is linked to plasma membranes by a glycophosphatidyl (GPI) anchor, deficiency of which results in Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria(PNH).

Reason: Absence of Decay-accelerating factor and CD59 results in complement-mediated lysis of red blood cells.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true, the reason is the correct explanation of assertion
Both assertion and reason are true but the reason is not a correct explain the assertion
Assertion is true but the reason is false
Assertion is false but the reason is true

questions.solution:
Decay-accelerating factor (DAF) and CD59 are two proteins that are linked to plasma membranes by a glycophosphatidyl (GPI) anchor.

DAF prevents the formation of C3 convertases and CD59 inhibits the formation of the MAC.

An acquired deficiency of the enzyme that creates GPI anchors leads to a deficiency of these regulators and excessive complement activation and lysis of red cells resulting in Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria(PNH).

questions.text: A 55 year alcoholic had repeated episodes of retching and vomiting after a meal. The patient now presents with severe sub sternal chest pain. His chest radiograph is given below. What will be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a translucent area around the heart which implies that there is air in mediastinum which is called as Pneumomediastinum.

The three main causes are:

  1. alveolar rupture with dissection of air into the mediastinum
  2. perforation or rupture of the esophagus, trachea, or main bronchi
  3. dissection of air from the neck or the abdomen into the mediastinum

Typically, there is severe sub sternal chest pain with or without radiation into the neck and arms. The physical examination usually reveals subcutaneous emphysema in the suprasternal notch and Hamman’s sign, which is a crunching or clicking noise synchronous with the heartbeat and is best heard in the left lateral decubitus position.

The diagnosis is confirmed with the chest radiograph.

Usually, no treatment is required, but the mediastinal air will be absorbed faster if the patient inspires high concentrations of oxygen.

If mediastinal structures are compressed, the compression can be relieved with needle aspiration.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the given instrument?

choices.text: It is a central IV line
It is an atypical form of Foley's catheter
It is used to remove emboli
It is used to inject dyes in the radiological intervention

questions.solution:
The given image depicts Fogarty's catheter. It is used for the removal of an embolus in cases of sudden arterial occlusion. 

 Management of sudden arterial occlusion:

  1. First-line management- intravenous heparin 5000 IU. Postoperatively, heparin therapy is continued until long-term anticoagulation with warfarin is established
  2. Definitive management (<6 hours)-
    • Embolectomy with Fogarty’s balloon catheter
    • Thrombolysis with tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) 

A CT angiogram is performed after the procedure to ensure that the flow to the distal leg has been restored.

Ischaemia beyond 6 hours is usually irreversible and may result in limb loss.

Complications of arterial revascularization:

  • Compartment syndrome
  • Reperfusion syndrome
  • Ischaemic neuropathy
  • Myoglobinuria
  • Renal failure

 Usually, a prophylactic fasciotomy is done in patients undergoing revascularization surgery to prevent compartment syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is an above ankle amputation:
questions.solution:
Symes amputation is an above ankle amputation. Here the level of the bone section is 0.6 cm proximal to the ankle joint.

  • Option a: Pirogoff is a type of below ankle amputation. (Removal of forefoot and talus followed by calcaneotibial arthrodesis)
  • Option c: Chopart’s amputation is partial foot amputation through the mid-tarsal joint.
  • Lisfranc amputation is partial foot amputation through the tarsometatarsal joint.

questions.text:
Match the named test and the agent that gives a positive result:
Column A Column B
Hopkins-cole test Tryptophan
Millon's test Tyrosine
Sakaguchi's test Arginine
Cyanide Nitroprusside test Homocysteine
  Galactose
questions.solution:
1. Hopkins cole test (glyoxylic acid reaction) is a chemical test used for detecting the presence of Tryptophan. A protein solution is mixed with Hopkins Cole reagent, which consists of glyoxylic acid. Concentrated sulfuric acid is slowly added to form two layers. A purple ring appears between the two layers if the test is positive for tryptophan.
  2. Millon's test is a chemical test to detect the presence of Tyrosine. A reddish-brown colouration or precipitate indicates the presence of tyrosine residue.
  3. Sakaguchi’s test is used for detecting the presence of Arginine. Sakaguchi reagent consists of 1-Naphthol and a drop of sodium hypobromite. The guanidine group in arginine reacts with Sakaguchi reagent to form a red-coloured complex.
  4. Cyanide Nitroprusside test detects the presence of Homocysteine.

Mucic Acid Test detects the presence of Galactose. Oxidation of galactose by concentrated nitric acid yields insoluble mucic acid.

questions.text: A  wool farmer presents with a hemorrhagic lesion on his left index finger for 3 days. On examination, he is febrile and lymphadenopathy is present. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image showing small, red hemorrhagic pustules with the given scenario is suggestive of orf or ecthyma contagiosum.

It is caused by the parapox virus. The commonly affected sites are hands and forearms. Lymphadenitis, lymphangitis, and fever are often present. 

It presents with a single lesion—a small, firm, red, or reddish-blue papule that develops after 5–6 days at the site of contact with an infected animal (mostly sheep and goats) and enlarges into a hemorrhagic pustule. The epidermis of an orf lesion shows ballooning degeneration of keratinocytes with eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions.

Treatment is usually not necessary, and the lesions heal after 3-6 weeks.

questions.text:
Choose the appropriate response considering the following image
  1. The device shown in the image is a Slit Lamp Biomicroscope.
  2. It can be used to visualise the anterior chamber of the eye.
  3. The device shown in the image is an Optical coherence Biomicroscope
  4. It can be used to visualise the posterior chamber of the eye.
  5. It can be used to visualise the Retina.

choices.text: Only a and e are correct
Only c and e are correct
a, b and d are correct
b, c and d are correct

questions.solution:
The device shown in the image is a Slit Lamp Biomicroscope.

  • It can be used to visualise the anterior and posterior chambers of the eye. It cannot be used to visualise the retina directly, because of the refractive power of ocular media.
  • Most slit-lamp microscopes offer magnifications between ×5 and ×50, with ×10, ×16, and ×25 being the most popular. Image resolution is ultimately limited by diffraction.
  • Because the cornea has such a high refractive power, the slit-lamp microscope can view only the first one-third of the eye. Special lenses, in conjunction with the slit-lamp microscope, can be used to view the posterior vitreous and the posterior pole retina.
