questions.text: Project “Axshya” is in relation to controlling which of the following disease?
questions.solution:
Project Axshya was launched in 2010 to control TB. Axshya means ‘free from TB’ which is the ultimate goal of the project and the national TB programme.

Project Axshya is being implemented by The International Union Against Tuberculosis and Lung Disease (known simply as The Union). The project works to improve access to quality TB care and control through a partnership between government and civil society.

The guiding principles of project Axshya are:

  • Universal access to quality TB services
  • Community participation in TB care and control
  • Sustainable interventions and equitable distribution of project benefits with social and gender sensitivity

questions.text: The shaded region in the given diagram indicates:
questions.solution:
The shaded region indicates the area of accepting a null hypothesis. 

The given diagram is a normal distribution curve. The shaded region indicates Mean ± 2SD.

The 95% confidence interval consists of all values less than 1.96 standard errors away from the sample value, testing against any population value in this interval will lead to p > 0.05. Thus this is an area of accepting the null hypothesis.

questions.text: Which of the following examples best describes a positive feedback mechanism?

choices.text: Blood calcium level on Parathyroid hormone
Decreased blood pressure on sympathetic outflow to heart
Effect of PaO2 on respiratory rate

questions.solution:
Increasing estrogen levels at midcycle (menstrual cycle) stimulates secretion of FSH and LH by anterior lobe of pituitary is an example of positive feedback.

Others are classic examples of negative feedback. When PaO2 decreases, respiratory rate increases (chemoreceptors). Low calcium levels in blood stimulates PTH secretion.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about Afrezza?

choices.text: It is available as a powder for inhalation

questions.solution:
Afrezza is an inhalational form of insulin that can cause hypoglycemia.

It is a rapid-acting form of insulin that is administered at the beginning of each meal. Peak levels are achieved 12-15 minutes later.

Adverse effects include hypoglycemia, cough, throat pain, or irritation. It may cause acute bronchospasm in patients with asthma, COPD, as well as active smokers. Hence, it is contraindicated in these condition.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old female patient has come to the medicine OPD with complaints of fatigue for the past 3 months. She has an 8-year-old son and there is no history of any chronic illness. She has been on the oral contraceptive pill for the past year. Peripheral smear findings are as given below.

Her laboratory investigations show:

  • Hb - 5.3gm%
  • TLC - 1100cells/mm3
  • MCV - 102fl
  • MCH - 40 pg
  • MCHC - 32g/dL

Which among the following is not a bone marrow finding of the above condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a female consuming oral contraceptive pills presenting with fatigue, laboratory values showing anemia, increased MCV and MCH, normal MCHC, and the peripheral smear showing Howell-jolly bodies, basophilic stippling, and hypersegmented neutrophils are suggestive of megaloblastic anemia. Megaloblasts in the bone marrow will show a nucleus with prominent nucleoli and a fine nuclear chromatin pattern. Pyknotic nuclei in megaloblasts is not a bone marrow finding in this condition.

Megaloblastic anemia:  There is impairment of DNA synthesis that leads to ineffective hematopoiesis and distinctive morphologic changes, including abnormally large erythroid precursors and red cells.

The cause of megaloblastic anemia is either Vitamin B12 deficiency or folic acid deficiency. Both can occur as a result of impaired absorption or inadequate intake. Oral contraceptives may impair the absorption of folic acid.

The peripheral smear will show:

  • Macro-ovalocytes with aniso and poikilocytosis.
  • Most macrocytes lack the central pallor of normal red cells and even appear hyperchromic, but the MCHC is not elevated.
  • The reticulocyte count is low.
  • Nucleated red cell progenitors occasionally appear in the circulating blood when anemia is severe.
  • Neutrophils are also larger than normal (macro polymorphonuclear) and show nuclear hypersegmentation, having five or more nuclear lobules.

The following image shows the peripheral blood smear findings in megaloblastic anemia.

Bone Marrow:

  • Markedly hypercellular as a result of increased hematopoietic precursors.
  • Large hematopoietic precursors- megaloblasts.
  • Since the nuclear maturation is delayed, the precursors retain fine nuclear chromatin instead of having clumped pyknotic nucleus.
  • The hemoglobin accumulation in the cytoplasm is normal, while the nuclear maturation is delayed. This leads to nuclear-to-cytoplasmic asynchrony. 
  • Granulocytic precursors also display dysmaturation in the form of giant metamyelocytes and band forms.
  • Megakaryocytes, too, can be abnormally large and have bizarre, multilobate nuclei.
  • The derangement in DNA synthesis causes most precursors to undergo apoptosis in the marrow (ineffective hematopoiesis) and leads to pancytopenia.

questions.text: When a medical student taps on the patellar tendon, which of the following type of nerve fiber is stimulated?
questions.solution:
When the patellar tendon is tapped, quadriceps muscle attached to it is stretched which activates Ia afferent fibers of muscle spindle which are arranged in parallel to the muscle.

Ia fibers subsequently synapse with the alpha motor neuron in the spinal cord which causes a reflex contraction of the muscle in order to return it to its resting length.

questions.text: The true statement about the following curve is:
questions.solution:
The given image is Receiver operating characteristic curve (ROC).

The X-axis indicates the false positive rate which is 100-specificity. The Y-axis is True positive rate which is the sensitivity.

The shape of the curve reflects the quality of the test. The better the test the more the curve towards the upper left.

The quality of the test can be quantified in terms of AUC. When the AUC is 1 (upper left-hand corner)  the test is best.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man who was diagnosed with HIV recently was started on HAART. Patients CD4 cell count subsequently decreased below 200/mm3. During the course of the next few months, he develops diarrhea and notices redistribution of fat on his body. Which of the following drug is responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Protease inhibitors are known to cause gastrointestinal tolerance and fat redistribution.

HAART therapy includes 2 nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors and protease inhibitors +/- NNRTIs.

Fusion inhibitor (Enfuvirtide) is associated with reactions at injection site.

NNRTI (efavirenz, delavirdine, nevirapine) cause hepatitis, drug rash.

NRTI’s (Zidovudine, lamivudine, emtricitabine) can cause peripheral neuropathy, pancreatitis, and gastrointestinal intolerance.

questions.text: The following instrument is used in:
questions.solution:
The instrument is a haemorrhoid stapler. It is used in hemorrhoidopexy.

The aim of this new operative approach is to reduce the size of internal hemorrhoids by interrupting their blood supply, therefore reducing the size of the vascular cushions and reducing the rectal mucosa for the potential of prolapse.

This procedure is associated with less postoperative pain as there is no perianal wound and the rectal wall above the dentate line has an insensitive mucosa.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding the given statements:

Assertion: Carcinoid tumors arising from the jejunum can cause carcinoid syndrome even before metastasize to the liver.

Reason: Due to increased production of 5-HT from tryptophan, some patients suffering from carcinoid syndrome have niacin deficiency.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true, the reason is the correct explanation of assertion
Both assertion and reason are true but the reason is not a correct explain the assertion
Assertion is true but the reason is false
Assertion is false but the reason is true

questions.solution:
When carcinoid tumor from the small intestine metastasizes to the GI tract it causes carcinoid syndrome.

This is because 5-HT and other substances produced by the tumor undergoes the first-pass metabolism and gets deactivated.

Since tryptophan is shunted towards the production of serotonin(5-HT), niacin deficiency occurs in some patients.

Related Pearl: Carcinoid syndrome

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the clinic complaining of difficulty in breathing. He has a history of road traffic accident 1 year back during which he received prolonged intubation for respiratory support. The flow-volume loop of the patient is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history and the flow volume loop point toward the diagnosis of tracheal stenosis and the history of prolonged intubation is a risk factor for tracheal stenosis. The graph depicts air flow limited during both inspiration and expiration leading to flattening of both the inspiratory and expiratory limbs, which is seen in fixed obstruction of the central or upper airway. 

 

A normal flow-volume loop begins on the X-axis (Volume axis): at the start of the test, both flow and volume are equal to zero. After the starting point, the curve rapidly mounts to a peak: Peak expiratory flow (PEF).

Then, the PEF the curve descends (=the flow decreases) as more air is expired. A normal, non-pathological F/V loop will descend in a straight or a convex line from the top (PEF) to the bottom (FVC).

The forced inspiration that follows the forced expiration has roughly the same morphology, but the PIF (Peak Inspiratory Flow) is not as distinct as PEF.

Classification of the lung pathologies based on this is - 

 

Other options - 

Option A: In COPD, the flow-volume loop shows a concave upward, pattern in the expiratory limb. This is also called the "scooped-out" or "coved" pattern. 

 

Option B: In vocal cord paralysis, the flow-volume loop shows airflow limitation and flattening in the inspiratory limb of the loop. It is an example of nonfixed variable extrathoracic obstruction. 

 

Option D: Obstructive sleep apnea shows a sawtooth pattern of the loop consisting of small, rapid oscillations inflow during both expiration and inspiration. It is seen in neuromuscular diseases, Parkinson's disease, laryngeal dyskinesia, pedunculated tumors of the upper airway, tracheobronchomalacia, upper airway burns, etc

questions.text: Choose the True/False among the following statements with respect to Delusional disorders:
questions.solution:
1. Delusional disorder with delusions of infidelity has been called conjugal paranoia when it is limited to the delusion that a spouse has been unfaithful. The eponym Othello syndrome has been used to describe morbid jealousy.
  2. Olfactory reference syndrome is a type of Somatic delusion and has an earlier age of onset (mean, 25 years), male predominance, single status and absence of past psychiatric treatment.
  3. Delusions of grandeur (megalomania) were first described by Kraepelin.
  4. Capgras syndrome, named after the French psychiatrist who described the illusion des sosies or the illusion of doubles. The delusion in Capgras syndrome is the belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an impostor. Others have described variants of the Capgras syndrome, namely, the delusion that persecutors or familiar persons can assume the guise of strangers (Fregoli’s phenomenon).
  5. Cotard syndrome is also called as Nihilistic delusional disorder, Patients with this syndrome complain of having lost not only possessions, status, and strength but also their heart, blood, and intestines.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding the given statements:

Assertion: Patients suffering from Chronic granulomatous disease(CGD) have increased susceptibility to catalase positive organisms such as Staphylococcus, E coli, and Aspergillus spp.

Reason: Macrophage-rich chronic inﬂammatory reaction that appears at sites of infection form granulomas in an effort to wall off the microbes.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true, the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true but the reason is not a correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is true but the reason is false
Assertion is false but the reason is true

questions.solution:
Patients suffering from CGD have increased susceptibility to catalase positive organisms because these organisms are able to neutralize the reactive oxygen species and hence the phagolysosome of the host is left without any ROS to attack the microbes.

CGD results from inherited defects in the genes encoding components of phagocyte oxidase, the phagolysosomal enzyme that generates ROS such as superoxide (O2•), resulting in defective bacterial killing and susceptibility to recurrent catalase positive bacterial infection.

Related Pearl: Chronic granulomatous disease

Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is due to the defect in NADPH oxidase. This interferes with the killing of bacteria by oxidative burst. Hence, the patients are at increased risk of infection from catalase-positive bacteria.

 It can be:

  • X linked - Defect in one of the membrane-bound components (gp91phox) or
  • Autosomal recessive - Cytoplasmic components (p47phox and p67phox)

Diagnosis of CGD includes:

  • Nitroblue tetrazolium test - This is the standard for phagocyte oxidase activity measurement. The colorless compound NBT is reduced to blue formazan by the activity of the functional phox enzyme system. Normally, more than 95% of the granulocytes will be positive. The NBT is negative in CGD due to absence of phox enzyme activity.
  • Dihydrorhodamine (DHR) test - The most accurate diagnostic test for CGD. Normally functioning phagocytic cells oxidize DHR to the strongly fluorescent compound rhodamine which is quantified by flow cytometry.

questions.text: Which of the following is the diluting segment of the kidney?
questions.solution:
The ascending thick limb of the loop of Henle is called the diluting segment.

In the ascending limb, there is the movement of Na+ and Cl– out of the tubular lumen, and the tubular fluid becomes more dilute.

When the fluid reaches the top of the ascending limb, it becomes hypotonic to plasma.

questions.text: Neurofilaments are found in:
questions.solution:
Neurofilaments are found in axons of neurons. It is a type of intermediate filament.

Type of intermediate filament Description
Lamin A, B, and C These proteins are localized in the nuclear lamina of all cells. The nuclear membrane laminins are responsible for maintaining nuclear morphology and nuclear transcription. Mutations In laminin proteins is associated with certain disorders such as muscular dystrophy, progeria.
Vimentin These are mainly found in mesenchymal cells (fibroblasts, endothelium)
Desmin Present in sarcomeres in muscle cells.
Neurofilament These are present in the axons of neurons and imparts strength and rigidity.
Glial fibrillary acidic protein Glial cells around neurons.
Cytokeratins These proteins are the most diverse among IFs and constitute type I (acidic) and type II (basic) IF proteins. There are at least 30 isoforms of this protein divided into two groups: Epithelial keratins (Found in epithelial cells) Trichocytic keratins (Found in hair keratin)

questions.text: A person presents to the emergency department with suspected poisoning due to ingestion of arsenic-containing pesticides 6 hours ago. Which of the following would you not expect to find?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is indicative of acute arsenic poisoning. Mees lines are unlikely to be found in a patient with arsenic ingestion 6 hours ago. It is seen in chronic poisoning. 

Features of acute arsenic poisoning:

  • Severe watery diarrhea (like cholera)
  • QTc prolongation and cardiac arrhythmias
  • Acute encephalopathy
  • Renal injury with acute tubular necrosis
  • Garlic odor of breath and stools

Mees lines are horizontal 1 to 2 mm white lines on the nails, also called transverse leukonychia. They occur due to a disturbance in the nail matrix keratinization. It may be seen 4 to 6 weeks after acute arsenic ingestion. These can also be seen in thallium poisoning.

The image given below shows Mees lines.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR) except:

choices.text: It is a type 3 hypersensitivity reaction

questions.solution:
AHTR is type 2 and not type 3 hypersensitivity reaction.

Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR):

  • Occurs within 24 hours of transfusion
  • Fever, flank pain, hemoglobinuria, renal failure and DIC
  • Caused by ABO incompatibility, Type 2 hypersensitivity reaction
  • Positive Direct Coomb's test, pink plasma
  • Transfusion to be stopped immediately

Delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction (DHTR):

  • Occurs 2-10 days after transfusion
  • Mechanism: Occurs in patients previously sensitized to RBC antigens. They have a negative antibody screen due to low antibody levels. When the patient is transfused with antigen-positive blood, an anamnestic response results in the early production of alloantibody that binds donor RBCs. The transfused, alloantibody-coated RBCs are cleared by the reticuloendothelial system.
  • Clinical features: Mild fever and hemolytic anemia, post-transfusion coomb's test positive (circulating donor RBCs coated with antibody or complement), positive new antibody screen.
  • Treatment: Supportive, additional transfusions may be required

Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR):

  • Starts within 1-6 hours of starting transfusion
  • Fever and chills
  • Mechanism
    • Antibodies directed against donor leukocyte and HLA antigens (sensitization)
    • More common in multiply transfused patients and multiparous women
    • Cytokine accumulation during blood storage
  • Treatment: Stop transfusion, antipyretics
  • Prevention: Leukoreduced products

Allergic/ Urticarial reactions:

  • Occurs within 2-3 hours of transfusion
  • Urticaria, flushing, angioedema, pruritis
  • Caused by recipient IgE antibodies and mast cell activation

Anaphylactic reaction:

  • Within few seconds-minutes of transfusion
  • Rapid onset of shock, respiratory distress, angioedema
  • Usually occurs in sensitized IgA-deficient recipients who produce anti-IgA antibodies that react with IgA in the transfused blood product.
  • Individuals with severe IgA deficiency should, therefore, receive only IgA-deficient plasma and washed cellular blood components.

questions.text: The histopathological finding given in the image below is most likely to be present in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The histopathological section has giant cells with a central ring of nuclei with a clear peripheral cytoplasm suggestive of the Touton giant cell. It is seen in xanthoma.

TOUTON GIANT CELL:

Touton giant cells are characterized by central eosinophilic cytoplasm and annulus of nuclei surrounded by a foamy, lipid-filled pale outer ring. These cells are seen in:

  • Fat necrosis
  • Xanthogranuloma
  • Dermatofibroma
  • Xanthoma

Other options

Options A and D: Langhans' giant cells are seen in tuberculosis and leprosy.  Langhans’ giant cells have a horseshoe-shaped nuclei arrangement at one pole of the cell. These are formed by the fusion of epithelioid cells. They are not phagocytic but secrete interleukins and help in inflammation.

Option C: Sarcoidosis: There are non-caseating granulomas composed of epithelioid macrophages with giant cells. There is no central necrosis. They are called naked granulomas as they are minimally surrounded by lymphocytes.

Laminated calcium and protein-containing bodies called Schaumann bodies (shown in the image below) and star-shaped inclusions called asteroid bodies are also found in the giant cells of most of these granulomas. These are not pathognomonic to sarcoidosis and can also be found in other granulomatous diseases like tuberculosis.

Related Pearl: Types of granulomas

questions.text: Color discrimination is diminished in which of the following type of cataract?
questions.solution:
Nuclear cataract reduces color discrimination significantly.

They are usually bilateral and patient notices the difference after one eye is operated. Progressive yellowing or browning of lens causes poor color discrimination towards the blue end of visible spectrum.

questions.text: The occurrence of a single case of the following diseases are considered as an outbreak except:
questions.solution:
The occurrence of a single case of malaria is not considered as an outbreak.

An outbreak is a sudden increase in the occurrence of a disease in a particular time and place.

A single case of a communicable disease long absent from a population, or caused by an agent not previously recognized in that community or area or emergence of a previously unknown disease may also constitute an outbreak and should be reported.

Warning signs of an impending outbreak:

  1. Clustering of cases or deaths in time/space.
  2. An unusual number of increase in the number of cases or deaths.
  3. Even a single case of Measles, JE, Dengue, Cholera, plague, and Acute flaccid paralysis.
  4. Acute febrile illness of unknown etiology
  5. The occurrence of two or more epidemiologically linked cases of meningitis or measles
  6. Unusual isolate
  7. Shifting in the age distribution of cases
  8. Sudden increase /high vector density
  9. Natural disasters

questions.text: True statement about the phenomenon seen in the image below:

choices.text: The cells being engulfed is destroyed immediately
A cell engulfs the cell of same type
The cell being engulfed undergo division inside the host cell
The above condition helps in the destruction of dead cells

questions.solution:
The above image showing a cell within a cell is termed as emperipolesis.

Emperipolesis is a condition where living and intact state hematopoietic cells are seen in the cytoplasm of a host cell without any damage. Both of these cells remain viable without any physiological or morphological changes. The cells taken in are neutrophils, lymphocytes, and plasma cells. The host cells may be a megakaryocyte, monocyte, endothelial cell, fibroblast, or malignant cells. The engulfed cell is enclosed in a membrane-bound vacuole in the cytoplasm of the host cell. Internalized cells appear to continue living within the host cell for brief periods of time. Sometimes they even undergo division within the vacuole.

Phagocytosis differs from emperipolesis as the engulfed cells are dead or dying cells or other materials from the extracellular space  (Option A and D). Phagocytosis also uses the host cell cytoskeleton to form pseudopodia and engulf the dead material. 

Entosis is a phenomenon where a cell engulfs a cell of the same type (Option B). While cells that are internalized by this mechanism are initially viable, the majority of them undergo a non-apoptotic form of cell death.

questions.text: If the prevalence of diabetes in a population is 20%, the probability that all 3 people selected at random from the population will have diabetes
questions.solution:
The probability that all 3 people selected at random from the population will have diabetes is 0.008%.

In this scenario, 3 individuals having diabetes are independent of each other. The events are mutually exclusive and are statistically independent.

Applying the multiplication rule of probability the probability of all the 3 individuals having diabetes is p(A)×p(B)×p(C)=0.2×0.2×0.2=0.008

 

Related Pearl: Probability

  • Expressed as a decimal fraction never as a percentage. Denoted by p
  • Must lie between 0 (zero probability) and 1 (absolute certainty).
  • Probability of an event cannot be negative.
  • The probability of an event not occurring (q) is q= 1-p

Rule

Description

Example

The Addition Rule

(p) of any one of several particular events occurring = the sum of their individual probabilities, provided the events cannot both happen and are mutually exclusive.

Probability of picking a heart card from a deck is 0.25 and that of picking a club is 0.25. Thus the p (hearts or clubs) is 0.25 + 0.25 = 0.50.

The Multiplication Rule

(p) of two or more statistically independent events all occurring is = product of their individual probabilities.

If the lifetime probability of a person developing a lung neoplasm is 0.25 and the life time probability of developing dementia is 0.01, then the p (lung neoplasm and dementia) is 0.25 x 0.01 = 0.0025.

The Binomial Distribution

 

(p) of the occurrence of a specific combination of mutually exclusive independent events.

The events for which binomial distribution is used have only two outcomes like yes or no, tall or short, male or female, etc.

 

Widely used in genetic counseling.

questions.text: Which of the following phases of  a clinical trial is also referred to as efficacy trial?
questions.solution:
Efficacy is the main aim of phase 2 of clinical trials.

Phase II of clinical trials involves a small group of patients (50-500). The new drug is administered for the first time in patients with the target disease at a dose that was judged safe in the phase I studies. Phase II studies are designed to obtain efficacy, proof of concept (potential of the drug to treat the disease) and dose-ranging (provides input for choosing the most appropriate dose for phase 3 studies).

Phase 3 studies are also known as pivotal studies or effectiveness studies. They determine if the new drug provides an improvement in the general health of the population and thus establish treatment benefits. While efficacy is also measured in phase 3 studies, phase 2 studies are more important for determining efficacy. 

Related Pearl: Phases of Clinical Trials

Usually the observational or open-label

Human pharmacology and safety: To determine safety, tolerability and pharmacokinetic parameters

Therapeutic exploration and dose-ranging: To determine efficacy and dose-ranging

 

Therapeutic confirmation and comparison: Indications are finalized and guidelines for therapeutic use are formulated. Monitoring of adverse reactions is done. 

Postmarketing surveillance: To monitor drug interactions, compliance and long-term or rare side effects

questions.text:
Theme and focus: Chest pain

Option list:

  1. Costochondritis

For each of the following patients as described in the scenarios below, identify the cause from the above answer option list:
questions.solution:
Case 1:

This is a case of costochondritis. The recent change in the workout schedule and the physical examination point toward this diagnosis. Costochondritis is inflammation of ≥1 costal cartilage. It commonly occurs in the 2nd to 5th costal cartilages. The examination finding of pain on palpation in costal cartilages is the clinching factor for the diagnosis of this condition. NSAID’s are the first line of treatment.

Case 2:

This is a case of a panic attack. Panic disorder is characterized by recurring unexpected panic attacks over a 1-month period. The time duration, agoraphobia, hypochondriacal concerns, and high medical utilization point towards the diagnosis of panic attacks. The physical symptoms of panic attacks like tachycardia, chest pain, and perspirations can mimic myocardial infarction. SSRI, SNRI, MAO, Benzodiazepines can be used to treat panic attacks. Benzodiazepines have a more rapid onset of action compared to the other options.

Case 3:

This is a case of pulmonary embolism(PE). Pulmonary embolism here is a consequence of thrombus formation within the lower extremities. The H/o recent immobilization, surgery, tachycardia and tachypnea are the points in favor of this diagnosis. Symptoms of PE include chest pain, cough, and symptoms of deep venous thrombosis. Suspected PE should be approached with clinical, pretest probability assessment, D-dimer testing, and definitive
diagnostic imaging.

Other options:

C. Boerhaave's syndrome is a spontaneous perforation of the esophagus that results from a sudden increase in intraesophageal pressure. It is most commonly seen during vomiting or straining. It is characterized by the sudden onset of excruciating chest pain and can progress to sepsis and shock in a few hours.

D. Pneumothorax is an abnormal collection of air in the pleural space between the lung and the chest wall. Symptoms typically include sudden onset of sharp, one-sided chest pain and shortness of breath.

E. Pericarditis is inflammation of the pericardium. Symptoms typically include sudden onset of sharp chest pain radiating to the shoulders, neck, or back. It is typically better sitting up and worse when lying down or breathing deeply. Other symptoms may include fever, weakness, palpitations, and shortness of breath.

F. Stable angina: chest pain or discomfort that most often occurs with activity or emotional stress.

H. Aortic dissection: Presents with abrupt onset severe chest or back pain, presence of pulse deficit and new-onset diastolic murmur (due to acute AR)

Related Pearl: Risk Factors for Venous Thromboembolism

The risk factors for venous thromboembolism (pulmonary embolism and DVT) are as follows:

  • Major trauma like spinal cord injury or fracture of lower limb
  • Surgery like hip or knee replacement
  • Hospitalization for heart failure or atrial fibrillation/flutter within last 3 months
  • Myocardial infarction within last 3 months
  • Previous venous thromboembolism
  • Infections and inflammatory bowel disease
  • Autoimmune diseases:
    • Antiphospholipid antibody (APLA)
    • SLE
  • Inherited thrombophilias:
    • Factor V leiden mutation
    • Deficiency of antithrombin III
    • Deficiency of protein C or protein S
  • Hypercoagulable states:
    • Pregnancy and postpartum period
    • COPD
    • Nephrotic syndrome
    • Polycythemia vera
    • Malignancies
  • Iatrogenic:
    • OCPs
    • Hormone replacement therapy
    • Chemotherapeutic drugs
    • Insertion of central venous lines
  • Varicose veins
  • Prolonged car or air travel.
